movie_review_blurb: ... it is a generous, warm and emotionally intelligent portrayal of female friendship across ages.

A mesmerising and highly imaginative documentary.
The characters will be familiar to fans of police procedural shows and TV movies.
A frothy end-of-summer treat.
The healing odyssey, directed by Michel Orion Scott, provides a powerful look at the complex condition of autism and family dedication.
His racial jokes have an edge, but they are not as deadly as the Chappelle's Show skits.
...an astonishingly graceful ballet performed with swords, arrows and fists.
Almodovar continues to refine the form of melodrama ... without sacrificing one iota of emotional texture or resonance.

...an experience that's both grueling and, in its way, glorious.
...a lean, mean entertainment that manages to be both playful and subversive while exhibiting plenty of mainstream appeal.
As with so much in the Islamic world, there are things here that are profoundly beautiful, as well as much that is profoundly scary.
movie_title: Kandahar: Le soleil derrière la lune (2001)

movie_review_blurb: It's dark and gritty and even a little tawdry, pushing ... deep into Death Wish territory, which is exactly as it should be.
KB2 is still basically a cartoon, albeit a more elaborately illustrated one...
...a work of enormous moral and spiritual depth, where sacrifice, forgiveness and redemption are revealed as the natural extensions of the movie's humdrum landscape.
...doesn't seem particularly interested in the nuances and points of frisson that are bound to occur when East meets West.

movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's a languorous and uncompromising work that will drive some to distraction, but also a movie of dark, still beauty that will have others weeping tears of pure, noir joy.
The erotic parlor games in Bertolucci's film don't get quite get debauched or deep enough, and once they've run their course, the movie doesn't know what to do.
The movie's biggest sin lies not in where it chooses to cast blame, but in its bungled attempt at manufacturing what I suppose you'd have to call an epiphany of excess.
A film with all the passion, mystery, tears and joy of first-rate, fully fleshed fiction.
It wavers between traditional period adventure, cynical, revisionist history and meandering, multi-character mini-series. The action scenes aren't very good either.
...Daniel and Susan just float around bitching at each other, so the movie frequently seems like a production of Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf in scuba gear.
...nowhere near the Coens' funniest or most distinctive or even most endearing work.
...a little bit like what Matthew Barney's Cremaster Cycle might have been without the illusions of grandeur or pretentious aftertaste.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: For all the talk, there's always something unspoken bubbling away in the space between these two ex-lovers...
An ungainly fusion of dutiful homage and snarky send-up.
A sprawling, ornately constructed entertainment.
What positions the film among Fellini's greatest are its punctuation points of mysterious beauty.

Ignore the scattershot approach, however, and there's considerable pleasure to be had in spending time with these bizarre enthusiasts and watching the creative ways they find to express their obsessions.
Craig's shaken-but-not-stirred charisma makes the most of an underwritten part, but the movie nearly flat-lines when the actor's not onscreen, which is often.
The Pink Conspiracy's solitary gag posits female bonding as a process so deeply malevolent it might give the most embittered misogynist pause.
...a passion play with a guy in drag (who could ask for anything more?)...
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Rest assured that all is resolved with a minimum of muss, fuss and imagination.
...eloquently written but not overwritten, with a story that ultimately feels less like a literary construct and more like a spontaneous celebration of a few lived lives...
...Millions pulls off the neat trick of affirming that money can't buy happiness, even as it has a ball pretending that it can.
...a movie that spews so much random, senseless, undigested matter that it seems more like projectile vomiting than filmmaking.
...a fascinating sort of connect-the-dots that allows us to essentially piece together our very own personalized portrait of this most curious of artists.
movie_title: In the Realms of the Unreal (2005)

movie_review_blurb: ...might just be the most extravagantly brutal live-action cartoon ever made.
...M. Knight Shyamalan trapped in a pornorgraphic art flick.

movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: ...Almodovar's meta-movie teases us with Big Ideas about those of us who love our fantasies so much that we turn them into our realities.
The film also triumphs as an insider's homage to an art form, playing at times like a survey of comedy history.
When the butts of the jokes are mid-level losers at meaningless conferences, the guerrilla theater seems misdirected, even cruel.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Director Havana Marking's work is quite moving, particularly when it follows two of the three women who compete with nearly 2000 male applicants for the title.
From an increasingly vibrant cinema about South Africa.
[It] could be the most aggressively terrible movie of the year.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: I was drawn in by the incredible beauty of Ida's photography to the point of alienation from the complex story through which such images unfolded in front of me.
Berberian Sound Studio follows Hitchcock's doctrine fully: what information audiences fill in with their imagination is always more horrifying than anything that can be filmed
Beautiful, difficult, frustrating, and engrossing, You Ain't Seen Nothin' Yet is an undeniable accomplishment of form and experimentation.
...a symphony of sound and image, an epic account of a dynamic and complicated relationship, and one of the most powerful and affecting love stories I've seen on film in quite some time.
...actors in supporting roles telegraph the controversies surrounding Arendt's personality as if they were attempting to literally touch the viewer's nose.
Far from an arthouse gimmick, Blancanieves marries style and story in a way that seems so obvious and fitting that it's a wonder why this film hadn't been made before.
Room 237 is about bringing a text to life through an active, prolonged, playful, or even tortured relationship to it. It's a document of immersive obsession.
Music Life is a film about a personality that carries little personality of its own.
One leaves The Pervert's Guide to Ideology with a lingering sense that this is how academic essay films should be done in the 21st century.
...perhaps there is an inherent contradiction in attempting to capture a democratizing movement through an individual figure, as rocktastic and badass as that figure might be.
More well-crafted experience than historical chronicle, Teenage is an illustrative portrait of adolescence from the attempted point-of-view of those who first made sense of it
How do you properly "restore" a site dedicated to preserving and displaying centuries of culture and history? [The film] details this impossible task, and it's thrilling.
...it's difficult to ascertain what the film has to say about underground hip-hop, or music in general, beyond showcasing the compelling independent artists at Stones Throw.
movie_title: Our Vinyl Weighs A Ton: This Is Stones Throw Records (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's an all-too-familiar coming of age tale, but the film gives us plenty of reasons to give a damn.

...the filmmaker and the very presence of the camera become a point of conversation and contention.
Herzog proves a formidable guide through several controversial conditions of American life: notably crime and punishment, and living with death.
Eames: The Architect and The Painter traverses the fascinating life of a couple whose contributions broadly determined what modern postwar American life looked and felt like.
movie_title: Eames: The Architect And The Painter (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a journey that takes us through unexpected, often harrowing twist and turns, unafraid to leave us perplexed, confused, or even frustrated.

[Breillat is] having fun with the genre and story as her template to toy with, then uses that foundation to engage with human sexuality as a subject.
Weitz's film-while certainly not always subtle-ultimately emerges triumphant and genuinely touching because of its graceful sincerity.
To fail at understanding, in this case, is exactly the point.
Weerasethakul is operating here in a specific liminal space between experimental artwork and arthouse filmmaking.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Superficial, forgettable, meaningless. It's simply bad storytelling, and by the end quite offensive.

...the film captures a woman who lives daily with the knowledge that she bears part of history.

movie_title: Don't Think I've Forgotten: Cambodia's Lost Rock And Roll (2015)

movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: ...a rich and respectful portrayal of hardcore music as a revitalizing vessel.

movie_title: Michael Jackson's Journey From Motown to Off the Wall (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A compelling, deep dive into a scandal that so many, especially the New York Post and Stephen Colbert, had painted as the simple - and crude - case of one prurient politician.

Neel has taken college drama tropes and made them nastier, darker and much more interesting.
What Dream is Destiny makes clear is that commercial success really isn't everything, and that being a director who isn't bothered by it can lead to a singular if perhaps undervalued career.
No hagiography, it paints a portrait of a life lived to the full and dedicated to being true to oneself.
movie_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise (2016)

movie_review_blurb: From its black-and-white presentation to its minimalist construction the film cries out arthouse, but there's a sense it's trying way too hard.

An immensely enjoyable, if predictable, ride.

The entire experience feels like it is leading up to a dramatic and well-needed climax, but sadly this never materialises and what we're left with is a run-of-the-mill yarn, albeit one with a stellar cast.

It's very hard not to get sucked in to the charm of this movie. Dano and Deschanel play their parts to perfection, exuding just the right amount of awkwardness and insecurity to bring the story to life.
This will certainly be a strong contender for movie of the summer and few will fail to be impressed by the breathtaking finale.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This fails to achieve anything special or spectacular and what we're left with is a rather run-of-the-mill, albeit more raunchy and definitely enjoyable, tale of opposites attracting.

Aliens In The Attic is a movie solely aimed at children and it does exactly what it sets out to do. It's nothing more than a harmless comedy for kids and tweenagers chock full of slapstick comedy, cute-as-pie aliens and appealing child stars.

Glossy, gorgeous to look at and filled with 'jump'-in-your-seat moments, this has all the hallmarks of a popcorn horror movie, complete with the ubiquitous shower scene, creepy abandoned cellars and characters' humorous nods to their own stupidity.
Where Paper Heart does shine, however, is in the reflections of the general public and few will fail to be moved by their truly inspiring and heartwarming stories of true love.
Worth a watch and does contain some truly spectacular special effects and intriguing performances.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Once you get past the ridiculous title and bombardment of moral messages, this is definitely worth a watch. Be warned though - you'll exit the cinema feeling surprisingly full and not wanting to touch spaghetti or hamburgers for a very long time!
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's no doubt that Me And Orson Welles is a sharp contrast to Efron's Disney days and will probably not appeal to his younger fans.

movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In the end not even a good comeback performance from Lopez can make this anything more than a forgettable date movie.

movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

... instead go rent "Shakes The Clown", a much funnier film with a similar theme and an equally great Robin Williams performance.

This could be the first movie since "Cool As Ice" that was outdated before it hit the screen.
This updated version could have been something very special, and as you watch it you can feel it brush past the cheek of greatness.
Almost Famous, this ain't. Instead, I'd call it "Almost Funny".
Williams creates a stunning, Taxi Driver-esque portrayal of a man teetering on the edge of sanity.
Quite frankly, I can't see why any actor of talent would ever work in a McCulloch production again if they looked at how this movie turned out.
Like the original Friday, this movie is overflowing with outrageous characters that will make you smile. Just watching them interact is worth the price of admission.
It would be enjoyed by anyone who has been married, is married, wants to get married, or knows someone who is married.
With Love, the 71 year-old Godard has created the film equivalent of a visit to your grandfather at the nursing home.

movie_review_blurb: A delightful little film that revels in its own simplicity, Mostly Martha will leave you with a smile on your face and a grumble in your stomach.

it's refreshing to see a movie that embraces its old-fashioned themes and in the process comes out looking like something wholly original.

a tightly constructed political thriller overflowing with fanatical terrorists, red-faced politicians, double-crossing spies and hidden agendas

Pacino and Williams seem to keep upping the ante on each other, just as their characters do in the film. What results is the best performance from either in years.
Star Wars is back in a major way.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Even fans of Ismail Merchant's work, I suspect, would have a hard time sitting through this one.

...this film goes beyond bad; it's borderline racist.
...there has been a great deal of thought and effort put into this film, and it shows.
...(for) anyone who thinks the medium is dying a slow, commercialized, "See Spot Run" death..."Mulholland Drive" is that glimmer of hope you've been waiting for.

A bleak, blistering, beautiful treasure of a film that presents wasted life in all its horrific vividness.

Probably the least controversial "controversial" documentary ever made.

Rarely has desperation been so intriguing, or so unabashedly sexy.
Butler has 2 goals: to show that Kerry was a hero and that Vietnam was wrong. Well, give any sensible person 5 minutes of your time and they could do it much more efficiently.

movie_review_blurb: If Phoenix is destined for greatness, this, his upcoming Johnny Cash biopic and last year's Buffalo Soldiers may be looked back on as the time he finally hit his stride.

...leaves the audience wondering whether it should laugh along or simply wince.
Very much the movie Metallica: Some Kind of Monster should have been. It captures a band at its peak, rather than just wallowing in the desperation that sets in years later.
movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Rarely have so many bad accents been on display, from the wandering German of the evil Major Cain to could-that-be-Russian? of two soon to be chomped soldiers.
In the context of the film, the scene where Anna and Sean make the rubber ducky blush is perfectly appropriate.
The CGI snakes are so blatantly computer-based that you expect them to occasionally pause and say 'You've got mail!
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Just close enough to Blade Runner to be great, but far enough away to make its own mark.

movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

We watch movies every day that celebrate violence, sex, and crude humor. Now, here's the chance to watch a movie that powerfully presents something worth celebrating: us.

A triumph for Twilighters.
Trick 'r Treat sequals

The script feels about ten re-writes short of being filmable.
"Helen" is a very heavy film. Heavier than Rosie O'Donnell at a Hometown Buffet.

movie_review_blurb: Mulligan does his best to get around Perkins' lack of baseball credibility, even laughably avoiding any shots of him fielding a groundball during the shortstop experiment.
Day-Lewis IS Jack, but no matter how large a font you could use on that capitalized two-letter word, it still wouldn't do his performance justice.
movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: As a die-hard Red Sox fan, the highest praise I can give Pixar's latest is that it held my full attention after a madcap and largely sleepless Victory Parade weekend.

Inspirational, entertaining and gripping.
Old McDonald had a farm, EEIEEIO. And on that farm there was no clear sense of direction, EEIEEIO.

Michael Keaton stares at a fuzzy TV image, waiting for something to happen; we stare at Michael Keaton, waiting for the same.

movie_review_blurb: The best biopic you're likely to see this year won't be coming to a theater near you.

movie_review_blurb: We're all goofy goobers deep down inside, and it's great news that there's finally a movie that invites us to embrace it.

Brutal, daring and utterly unpedictable - three qualities quite rare in movies these days.

More memorable for its performances than any facet of the plot, Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World sometimes feels as long as its title.

movie_review_blurb: A borderline classic, this is a movie that harkens back to such films as Casablanca, but still confidently asserts its own unique voice.

Move over, Elf. Australian director P.J. Hogan has put together an equally delightful holiday treat anchored by two magical lead performances.

A hypnotic masterpiece, it grabs hold and won't let go until you've fallen under its spell.

movie_title: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A decent, but completely forgettable sequel.

movie_review_blurb: Is it too late to toss Ice Cube's name into the hat in the new James Bond sweepstakes? I'd be down with that.

movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: (Daniel) Craig, an actor who'll be noticed whether or not he slips on Bond's tuxedo, continues to reveal a different side of himself in every role.

As popcorn entertainment, strapping in for Star Wars: Episode III is like hooking up with an old friend. Half the enjoyment is simply the idea of the reunion itself.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: My hat's off to the directors. They've given us a funny screen romp the family can enjoy together.

movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Just how bloody far are we supposed to suspend our disbelief for a slice-and-dice horror flick?

(Anthony) Anderson is funny, usually. Just not here.

movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Johnny Cash couldn't walk the line, but his bio never wavers.

Beautifully photographed, Balzac is a sometimes edgy journey that lands gently, but effectively on the mind.
movie_title: Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Disney runs history through the same Hollywood melodramatic redo that made Miracle, the Olympic hockey saga, such a crowd pleaser in 2004 and The Rookie a winning baseball film in 2002.

Last Holiday is the kind of film perfectly suited for those in the mood for something that doesn't require much more than a willingness to settle in for some warmhearted silliness. On that level, it's delicious.
More often than not, the look reflects a speeded-up trip though the hard drive to keep costs from skyrocketing. In other words, don't expect much detail.
The Passenger is one of the most fascinating film odysseys of the 1970s. I think someone invented the word cinema for films like this.
Go see Magnificent Desolation on the giant IMAX screen and Tom Hanks will moon-rock your world.
movie_title: Magnificent Desolation: Walking on the Moon 3D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Devout and delightful. That's a rare one-two punch for a feature film. Ushpizin pulls it off.
The only slipup is a forgivable one. Jackson continues to be reluctant to leave a world he has so magnificently created. At a little over three hours, King Kong is a bit of a bum-number.
It's a broad, slightly naughty comedy in musical form from the skewed, if not a little twisted, comic genius Mel Brooks.
Once again, Spielberg turns history into a riveting suspense-thriller.
Cinematographer Dione Beebe ... fills the screen with lavish images that constantly amaze the senses.
A not-so-funny comedy is something we've unfortunately learned to live with. But an unfunny comedy with Jim Carrey out front?
Rarely does a movie come with a homework assignment. Take it from me, though: Rumor Has It is a lot more fun if you've seen The Graduate.
Brokeback Mountain, like Sam Mendes' best-picture Oscar winner American Beauty, challenges its audience to embrace luminous filmmaking beauty even while spelunking through dark emotions.
Willis, last on screen in Sin City, put a rock in his shoe so he wouldn't forget that his broken man-character has a limp. His real crutch, though, is the boozed-up, flawed hero.
Spoofing on surprisingly solid footing for a third sequel, Scary Movie 4 continues the shift from horror to slap-shtick that director David Zucker began with No. 3 in 2003.
Will Ferrell is funny. Woody Allen is hilarious, or at least he was in his heyday. Will Ferrell channeling Woody Allen? Not so funny.
Oddly enough, Walt Disney Pictures breaks through the glass ceiling of modern animation with a tale about the sky falling.
There's not a whole lot going on. This is a war movie without a major battle. ... Mendes, a director of indisputable talent, just can't seem to find his footing.
Bollywood musical revelry mixes with vaudeville's grand tradition of slamming doors to accent the comedy and emotional chaos.
(Alex) Hutz can't get back on screen soon enough if you ask me. He displays enormous range for a first-time actor.
As (Fiennes) straps on toughness, courage and understanding, he is also molding one of his finest performances.
(Peter) Hyams gives us the worst green-screen scenes in modern history.
(Scott) Derrickson uses a visual sledgehammer. That tilts everything toward horror and dilutes the terrifying power of the supernatural darkness.
Eugene Levy, the most hilarious character actor on the planet, teams with stone-faced Samuel L. Jackson wonderfully.
Crowe's mood-indigo swing through the Sentimental South, an odd blend of whimsy and overly sentimental Hallmark moments, lacks the entertainment punch of his earlier work.
It's almost as if the power went out and Domino was filmed on back-up generator power complete with blackouts and power surges.
The Perfect Crime is an outrageous fiesta of decadence.
movie_title: The Perfect Crime (El Crimen Perfecto)(Crimen ferpecto) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Quality acting can overshadow a certain amount of plot and direction looseness, however. That's what makes In Her Shoes worth trying on.
(John) Madden and (Gwyneth) Paltrow are, once again, simpatico as collaborators.
Call it My Fair Lady with a gender switch, a betting line and an over/under.
It deserves to be the biggest thing in animated features since Shrek and quite possibly Toy Story.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Thumbsucker has something to say, and (Mike) Mills is tough enough and skilled enough to articulate the raw emotions of troubled youth.
Jim Jarmusch writes and directs the darkly comic relationship drama. With Bill Murray in the lead role, it's a marriage made in subtly droll heaven.
Some movies are to be consumed and discarded. History of Violence, a drama of disarming power, is not one of those. This is one of the most stirring films of the year.
Writer-director Joss Whedon resurrects a TV series one network canceled and no other wanted with sass and style.
(Roman) Polanski orchestrates this well-worn chestnut with the same high level of expertise that won him an Oscar for The Pianist in 2002.
What if grandpa was a hit man, and he was rapidly losing his mind during a killer assignment?
movie_title: De zaak Alzheimer (The Memory of a Killer) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The long delayed project ... churns out more cheese than a Wisconsin dairy, especially in the final reel.
When my body and spirit decide to go their separate ways, I want to be perky and beautiful like Reese Witherspoon in Just Like Heaven.
(Nicolas) Cage might just dip a toe into early Oscar consideration with this outing. He's that good.
If you've seen many schlock shockers, you won't have any trouble seeing where this one's slithering to long before it gets there.
Lila says what's on her mind. And what's on the frankly speaking, flirtatious blonde's mind is sex.
The foggy bottom boys are back and kicking up quite a fuss in The Fog, a fright-filled remake of John Carpenter's 1980 horror thriller.
(Charlize) Theron's Josey doesn't quite have the dramatic starch of Aileen, the man-hating hooker of Monster. It has more nuance, though.
Gallop, don't walk, to a movie house for one of the most uplifting live-action family films in years.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Its sole purpose appears to be to confuse, to muddle and to blow our minds.
Into the Blue is a fine-looking, often boring, eye candy palace to visit. Until the languid turquoise sea churns into a crimson tide, that is.
This is the kind of smart, embraceable romantic comedy Cary Grant and Katharine Hepburn might have made if they were alive and in their prime today.
Red Lights seethes with unexpected thrills around almost every corner. Antoine . . . has no clue to what lies ahead. ... Neither do we. That elevates the intrigue.
When his friends send him off to America to his town's sister city of New Braunfels for Wurstfest, Schultze begins to spiral out of control.
Those witty Brits. They may have lost the overseas colony that became the U.S. of A., but they sure know how to spice up a zombie flick with bloody humor.
Raw and in your face, Mean Creek eventually ripples emotions all the way to the soul.
(Kerry) Conran, a rare rookie director given free reign over his digital domain, takes his place as a gifted innovator of robust retro.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: As a comedy, Mr. 3000 is something just a little better than a whiff. The emotional change-up near the end could just turn it into a pinch hit, though.
If there's a sequel, could we please have some bubbles or stuff floating by to make it appear to be underwater next time?
(Billy Bob) Thornton and (Lucas) Black (who could mature into a true acting force) are magnificent together as the young, unsure quarterback and his caring coach/mentor.
Brutally violent, grotesquely gross and funny enough to make you fight not to wet your pants, Team America: World Police pegs the R-rated raunch meter.
This is a film that probably shouldn't work, but does. Shall we dance? Sure, just don't slip on the sloppy tears or the butterlike popcorn topping.
This is a spectacular movie that involves much more than just a compelling story. (Gael) Bernal doesn't just portray a young Che Guevara. He steps into his life and his soul.
(Barry) Tubb fills the screen with wholesome, live-action family entertainment. That's a rarity these days.
This is never a great film. In scattered stretches, though, it's a very good one.
Finally, the key to making an Americanized version of a Japanese film is revealed: Let the original director call the shots.
Affleck somehow remains convinced that he's a leading man. He does this despite mounting evidence to the contrary. ... Do I need to invoke the "G" word (Gigli)?
Foxx, at the center of the turbulence in the title role, turns in a remarkable, soulful performance. ... It might just have Oscar's golden statuette tapping its toes.
It may compel at first, but Birth just doesn't deliver, especially for those looking for anything resembling a logical payoff.
Even veteran horror fans that treat slice-and-dice crime dramas like this as emotional theme park rides are likely to feel unsettled at first.
This documentary works best for those who understand 'Hey, Ho!' and really want to go.
movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: I can't shake the notion that The Incredibles may not be all it might have been. It stomps all the expected bases instead of streaking by with daring innovation.
Law is a talented actor trapped in a male model body. He makes us care about this cad we shouldn't give a flip about through his ability to charm and disarm.
The story's good, the sets of Old London are terrific and memories of Andrew Dunn's cinematography will linger. The outstanding acting, though, that's the thing.
No matter where you stand on the jolly guy in the red suit, believe this. The Polar Express is the most magical, captivating animated Christmas adventure of all time.
It is a film of deep feeling, survival and sacrifice that's well acted and brought to the screen with style.
This would be fun if director Jon Turteltaub didn't move things along at a snail's pace.
I propose a toast to one of the best, and possibly most courageous, movies of 2004.
Bening's performance rises above the appeal of the movie itself. In fact, it's one of the strongest of the year.
(Moore's) a quadruple Oscar nominee ... with nothing left to prove. What's she doing in a cheesy popcorn flick like this? I think it's called paying the rent.
Although (Rhys) Ifans is a convincing force on screen, this role (and much of the film, really) feels like an odd fit.
If emotional tension is what you're after (and all you're interested in), though, We Don't Live Here Anymore is a provocative address for a one-night stand.
Wicker Park feels like an import stripping film sprockets as it struggles to fit the American mold. Advice from this aisle seat: Bring along a pad and pencil.
If The Benchwarmers were a real ball game, the mercy rule would end the punishment in the first 15 minutes.
Cuarón ... uses his enchanting vision to send Rowling's third installment down its dark, wondrous, often captivating road in grand style and with a generally steady pace.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Spider-Man 2 doesn't just come from Marvel, it is a marvel.
Anyone who counts on Hollywood to excavate history accurately deserves a movie in which Guinevere is a ferocious female warrior who wears only a leather harness as a top.
This is a wobbly comedy rooted too deeply in three- or four-minute TV-style set pieces, which misfire more often than not.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: So much for Gort and C-3PO. ... I, Robot explodes with some of the most impressive action sequences in years.
What we have here is a failure to communicate anything the least bit interesting unless you're under 10 and this is your first cinematic rodeo
Kline, a double Tony Award winner, is sublime, whether tinkling on the 88s or warbling Porter tunes. He obviously loves that skin he's in, even in the darker moments.
The Clearing, rather fuzzy in so many ways, is an incredibly slow-moving exercise in tedium.
Demme, an enigmatic filmmaker who successfully bounces between fiction and nonfiction, goes for the thrills here, leaving the chills to the original.
Let's face it. Shyamalan knows how to wield the cinematic fear factor. ... Maybe he's just running out of things with which to rattle us.
(This) isn't your typical lowbrow comedy about dopes smoking dope. Deep down, under the buns and fun, lurks a heapin' helping of heart.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Collateral, even though cowboyed up with implausible action in a couple of pivotal scenes, is that rarest of thriller. In this one, words can also kill.
Murphy, who dazzled opposite Eminem in 8 Mile, seemed close to budding-starlet burnout after the dismal comedy Just Married. She bounces back in this one.
With ... her command of the moment, (Moreno) could develop into an actress to watch in the future. One thing is certain. We can't take our eyes off her in this one.
This Princess falters before getting to the altar. Once that near-magical event happens (especially, if you're a little girl), the kingdom is enchanted once again.
Some of the dialogue is unintentionally funny. Early on, for instance, the narrator bellows: 'Even eternity doesn't last forever.'
Whether one installs the silent 'up a creek' preamble to the title depends on how you feel about serious silliness.
Anyone choosing to sit on the edge of a seat in a state of locked tension ... will be utterly fulfilled. ... The fuzzy nature by which the premise is presented bites.
This story is simplistic and budget-restrained at best. The script has little real mystery and no nuance. Frankly, the best acting comes from the canine co-stars.
Alien vs. Predator is a ton of alien-slobbering, bust-a-gut fun.
Martial artistic. That's the new term demanding to be coined for director Zhang Yimou's astonishing period drama.
This is a B-grade horror-thriller sequel with a no-name cast and more schlock than shock. For the record, the theme shed its skin seven years ago.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: There's so much going on in almost every frame, it quickly becomes exhausting, at least from this aisle seat.
Witherspoon dishes out disarming charm and surprisingly effective vulnerability. It's a performance worthy of Academy Award consideration.
For Joplin fans, this is an absolute must-see. Her soulful renditions of Cry Baby and ... Tell Mama may be the most telling Joplin concert footage ever captured.
Stone appears to be assembling this ... jigsaw puzzle on the fly. There are more bottom-out scenes than high points. He drags it out for almost three backside-numbing hours.
(Marc) Forster's subtle yet powerful blend of reality and Barrie's flights of mental whimsy combine for the rarest of the rare: cinematic excellence.
Skipping Christmas will earn you a reputation as a modern-day Scrooge. Passing on Christmas With the Kranks ... makes you a wise holiday-movie consumer.
As sequels go, this computer-effects invigorated wall-banger engages only slightly.
Pacino, bearded and digging deep within his talent, almost shrinks into human nothingness under the weight of hate. It may be his finest performance.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It must be a hoot when performed live. But it only works in spurts on screen.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Gutsy director Gurinder Chadha ... bends it like Bollywood this time -- the 'it' being the relatively sacred prose of British novelist Jane Austen.
Sequels rarely emerge as anything interesting, much less compelling. This one does. ... Warmed-over Chili is a gas.
Diesel seems more comfortable barking orders than maneuvering through the nuances of funny business.
It's curious that the assisted-suicide debate over a late plot twist in Million Dollar Baby didn't rage over this one. After all, Amenabar is dealing with a real life.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: When the violence-filled, snarling creature-fest appears to be over, there's another act to go. It should have quit when it was almost a hoot.
Robots breaks no new ground, just wind. If this marginally entertaining yarn makes any new strides, it's in ... robot-ily function toilet humor.
Old action heroes die hard. Bruce Willis regains blazing glory in Hostage, an action-thriller with more twists and turns than Mulholland Drive.
The only real ecstasy comes not from emotional enlightenment, but in the form of a pill at a college keg party.
Oh, Calcutta -- harsh and real like we've never seen it. ... This is one dazzling documentary that continues to develop.
In the Realms of the Unreal is a post-mortem salute to a prolific artist who lived meekly and took his epic achievement to the grave.
movie_title: In the Realms of the Unreal (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This time the prophecy of The Ring might just come true: You watch it, you die. Of boredom.
Ice Princess, though somewhat clichéd, combines the fire of passion for a dream with the frost of unscrupulous reality.
It's an odd little film with tremendous appeal. It's almost as if Zeffirelli ... has dug up a late-'70s time capsule to share with the world.
The overall premise is too flimsy to sustain an ongoing series. It should be two and through for Miss Congeniality.
I'm not ashamed to say that Ashton Kutcher made me laugh in Guess Who. OK, maybe I'm a little ashamed. But it was so unexpected I couldn't help myself.
Off the Map doesn't defy description. It is, however, shortchanged by it. This is a film that must be allowed to cast its hypnotic spell on its own terms.
Rory O'Shea, challenging and difficult to watch at times, is to be applauded for taking us about as close to reality as a situation like this allows.
(Robert) Rodriguez and his cohorts succeed for the most part. If this beguiling world of violence and degradation ... lacks in anything, it's knowing when to quit.
Beauty Shop won't change any lives. Like highlights on top of a familiar 'do, though, it'll brighten things for a while.
Don't go into The Upside of Anger expecting the usual convenient and happy Hollywood solution to serious problems. That, to me, is the real upside.
First-time documentary makers (Michael) Tucker and ... Petra Epperlein ... get a little bogged down in letting soldiers express their feelings through amateur rap.
As unfathomable as it may seem, Downfall might just summon some brief, but fleeting empathy for the devil, as it were.
A movie like Constantine is a huge undertaking. ... This is a vast canvas encompassing two worlds. It cries out for an experienced director, not a first-timer.
Forces of Nature doesn't just show nature at its angriest; this film explains how and why as well. It's a highly entertaining way to learn valuable lessons.
One wedding. No funerals. A pretty woman. Lots of borrowed somethings, but nothing new.
Boogeyman, shot in Auckland, lives and induces giggles instead of fear in yuckland.
It's about as mesmerizing as watching Clooney, Pitt, Roberts and the gang walk the red carpet at a movie premiere.
Underneath the hard-hitting wordplay lurks a crafty relationship drama. Complex and challenging, it plays out like a game of championship chess.
Even if (Wesley) Snipes zombie-walks through his part, how can you hate a horror-action flick that lets the vampire dogs out?
The Machinist doesn't take us to a happy place. For those who appreciate true mind-bending grit, though, this is the bedeviled place to be
This is the great mother-daughter movie of 2004. Everyone, however, will feel emotionally richer after sharing the heartfelt humanity.
By the time we get to this Phoenix, it looks like numerous days of scorching sun and blasts of sand are pretty much good for the complexion.
If you're tough enough to attend, however, be sure to stick around for the frisky closing credits. They're animals, I tell you.
A rascally little play on words is the funniest element of Meet the Fockers, a sequel with big name stars and, only occasionally, laughs to match.
This spectacle of a musical is constantly visually stunning and, more often than not, musically enriched.
When I look at Spacey in this film, I see Kevin Spacey, not Darin. This leaps out even more this winter because when I look at Jamie Foxx, I see Ray Charles.
(Bill) Murray's blank stare might be because there's nothing he can do to improve things. Usually it's a device he uses to accent eccentricity.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The Aviator, while not flawless, is, nonetheless Scorsese's Citizen Kane. Both are extravagant, melodramatic studies of brazen men out to change the world.
Matthew McConaughey ... makes a bid to become the next swashbuckling matinee idol. Not that there's much swash to buckle in the middle of the world's largest desert.
So much for 'rest in peace.'
It makes one wonder why the makers of an otherwise embraceable family comedy feel they need to go lowbrow to make kids laugh.
A major key to the success is (Topher) Grace's ability to hold his own in complicated scenes, especially with (Dennis) Quaid. This is a major breakout performance.
Bountiful in human spirit ... and martial arts action, House of Flying Daggers is like no other film. Except for Hero, which was like no other before it.
In addition to being an epic slice of riveting drama, Hotel Rwanda is that rare movie that can actually make a difference.
The Woodsman meets its key plot challenges without flinching. Those of us in the audience may not be able to do the same
At 74 and directing his 25th film, (Clint) Eastwood just keeps getting better behind the camera.
Do good actors make a lousy movie any better? A little. But they're wasting their time and ours. That creeps me out.
(Christian) Slater and (Tara) Reid share quite possibly the most awkward love scene ever recorded on film.
Cameron is no longer content to merely show what's down there. Aliens of the Deep also speculates about what might be up there. Way up there in outer space.
The date doctor operates like an overly eager comic intern. That's the only real glitch in Hitch.
Pooh's Heffalump Movie isn't just the best of the bunch (since 2001). As the silly 'ol bear with the sweet tooth would say, 'It's a hunny.'
Bad Education lacks the ample comic breathers (Pedro) Almodóvar often brings to lessen his dramatic blow. Perhaps this one hits too close to home to laugh off.
With the possible exception of Tommy Lee Jones, no one is better suited to dish out stone-faced, my-way-or-the-highway discipline than Jackson.
Unfortunately, the Ice Age sequel doesn't take a major step forward like Toy Story 2 in 1999.
The no-frills yet deeply gripping manner this film uses to document this brave soldier's struggle for survival, then in rehab, should draw a salute from military personnel and civilians as well.
Basic Instinct 2, with Sharon Stone once again in the seductress role, is a sordid tale of lying liars and pants on fire.
We celebrate joy rising from the ashes of tragedy.
For a playwright-turned-filmmaker still preaching pretty much to a choir of (Tyler) Perry's devoted near-cult following stage-play converts, however, it might be enough.

I wish the script credited to Michael Ian Black (The Pleasure of Your Company) and (Simon) Pegg had a little more intrigue along the way to its predictable finish.
Oh brother, George, where art thou going with this?
Unabashedly, this is a family entertainment package made for the child in all of us. And one more thing: It's fun. Lots of smart, if silly, escapism.
Finally, a horror-thriller that freaks you out and creeps you out without making you downshift your brain into moron mode.
Very well-acted, especially by (Carla) Ribas, this is a tense drama of friendship, family and deceit that explores a wide spectrum of raw emotions.
Prom Night boils down to an obsessed maniac (Johnathon Schaech) on the loose with a knife and a disappointingly routine, matter-of-fact plot that just doesn't cut it.
If you enjoy glib, offbeat humor, the smartest thing you might do all day is buy yourself a ticket.
Street Kings, unlike the recent cop drama Gone Baby Gone, feels like it slid out of a police precinct file cabinet and slapped itself on a movie screen.
This rarely happens, but I can't find a single negative thing to say about this intriguing, beautifully mounted slice of cinema.
Chicago 10 brandishes enough sickening reality (Chicago police clubbing protestors, etc.) to make the audience gasp with astonishment.
It's not that (Jason) Segel, a TV vet of How I Met Your Mother and one of the CSI series, looks like a normal guy. The problem is that he's also a blue-collar drone when it comes to acting.
Hoo-ha, Al, take the money and run.
Instead of hitting us with crouching tigers and hidden dragons, the kung fu action-adventure The Forbidden Kingdom features the monk versus the drunk. And it works.

The physical dimensions of Morgan Spurlock, whose funny, edgy documentary Super Size Me drew an Oscar nomination in 2004, have returned to normal size. His ego, on the other hand, remains a tad inflated.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: (David Gordon) Green's finest film in four attempts to pop the hood on human nature reveals not just conflicted human engines, but at least one character fighting to keep the wheels from coming off.
If you're tough enough to go with the filthy flow, Escape from Guantanamo Bay is, at times, bust-a-gut funny.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's fun to see a couple of talented, funny women head a comedy for a change.
It also doesn't help that the final reel reeks of preposterous event turns.
Their performances (Michel Joelsas, Daniela Piepszyk) %u2014 natural, poignant and wide-eyed about what life will serve up %u2014 are things of beauty.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Iron Man ... is really a four-act play in a three-act movie.
(Richard) Jenkins doesn't waste a motion or a word while bestowing on us an introspective acting clinic. They don't call them character actors for nothing.
It's a compelling journey into a soul-chilling past that might not be fully sorted out for generations to come.
This is not simply the case of a child learning his lines and delivering them in OK fashion. (Adrián) Alonso is an actor to be reckoned with, even as a young teen.
(Norah) Jones doesn't merely hold her own in a pouty screen debut of note; she looks comfortable and purrs with the confidence of someone who belongs.
Because the filmmakers plant their laugh-generating derrick over the same comic well that's been pumped out twice before, Drillbit Taylor hits a dry hole.
It'll be a long time before the image fades of members of the Alexandria Ceremonial Police Orchestra in their powder-blue regalia lining up formally as they struggle to maintain their dignity.
First Sunday, a self-described 'funny and heartwarming comedy,' stumbles in the comedy department, but fills the heart's collection plate with a strong inspirational finish.

Part of (the) sizable budget must have been spent on a medieval era cosmetic dental plan. I've never seen so many perfectly straight sparkling pearly whites in a time of brutes and hand-to-hand brutality.
movie_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The notion of no arms, especially when they're sword fighting and the swords just sort of float in front of their bodies, seems like a long way to go to establish unique cartoon characters.
movie_title: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In Spanish with subtitles, this magical, mystical tale seems anointed somehow with Del Toro's thick atmospheric elixir that served Pan's Labyrinth, Del Toro's unsettling Oscar-winner of last year.
The best comedy of the year beams with pregnant pauses
The Russians are going, the Russians are going
Alternately chilling and thrilling, The Kite Runner tugs at some emotional strings not often yanked with such frankness.
Introducing the diePhone
Ridley Scott forgets that editing is an art form as well
Untraceable may not rank as one of the best serial-killer thrillers of all time, but it packs enough punch to hold your attention way past the whodunit point.
Stallone, smarter than he looks and possessing fierce determination, pours as much heart into this one-man-army saga as he does movie blood.
Matthew McConaughey and Kate Hudson have the spar-flirt formula down pat.
There's more heart than one might expect in this raunchy romp across America.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you go to see Persepolis, you're going to do something you might not have expected to do in your life. You're going to fall in love with an Iranian girl.
Even though this raucous, low-low-lowbrow comedy hits theaters early in the year, I'm thinking the race for bottom-feeder of 2008 is, if not over, at least well under way.
No one will argue that Semi-Pro isn't crude and lewd. Thanks to Ferrell and his cast of crazies, however, it plays the lowbrow genre like an all-pro.
A grim fairy tale at times, Penelope eventually lands in crowd-pleaser territory.

I've got an idea for Larry the Cable Guy's next dumb movie. Maybe the lowbrow bumbler with the big heart and even bigger beer gut could play, oh I don't know, a cable guy?
Let's not go to the videotape.
I like the way (Nadine) Labaki brings character depth to everyone in her sizable ensemble.
(Neil) Marshall, once regarded as a filmmaker to watch, is inching precariously close to being one to forget.
If he's not a master at making audiences squirm, (Michael) Haneke (Caché) is close.
(Cristian) Mungiu creates great screen tension when he introduces the black-market abortionist.
Personally, I prefer the Thai original, which is available on DVD. It truly gave me the creeps.

If the Wachowski brothers still have one creative foot in their old, 'perfect' manufactured reality, it's a mom and pop matrix.
The combat, even the obligatory big fight, bruises bodies just as painfully as Mamet's killer words attack the soul.
... the Marx Brothers couldn't outrace the Coen boys when it comes to zany comic shenanigans.
It's good to see the two great actors of their generation back together in Righteous Kill. Frankly, though, although a few sparks of fire at times, the heat has subsided significantly.
Stone ... does little more than place a sitting president on a pedestal of lampoon with a poor choice of timing, less than three weeks before a presidential election.
Wahlberg packs the talent to add depth to most roles. In this one, though, he does little more than mope around and blast away (video-game style) in this barrage of rapid fire.
Visually, this one mirrors Cloverfield right down to the dropped camera left to record what happens when the humans in the vicinity have been, uh, quarantined.
... heads roll and nail bomb shrapnel turns a headstrong 'survivor' into a pile of pink human brisket with pants. Does this sound like entertainment to you?
This is the first time (Edward) Norton and (Colin) Farrell have shared a movie screen. It would be a crime for it to be the last.
They sing. They dance. And they smooch a little. But not too much. After all, this is a G-rated Disney extravaganza.
I Served the King of England plays like a combination of Life Is Beautiful and Forrest Gump.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If movies were fireworks, Smith's latest effort would be a fuse-moistened bottle rocket that only manages subdued flight.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Most filmmakers begin their careers hungry and looking for every possible nuance to improve their film. In his 78th year and with 35 of them under his belt as a filmmaker, Eastwood still has plenty of creative steam. ... This is no victory-lap production
The Haunting of Molly Hartley, sort of an updated Rosemary's Baby for teens, sucks most of the suspense out of its own suspense-thriller before the story even gets going.
Welcome back, Mr. Ritchie. I missed your work when you were, you know, Swept Away into an uncomfortable filmmaking zone.
Make a little room Lady, Tramp and all you Dalmatians, Disney's got a new animated dog to bark about.
How can a teen romantic fantasy not be at least some fun when the leading man's lipstick is several shades redder than that of the ingénue?
There is a Bond girl, of course. You can take the catchphrases and the gadgets out, it appears, but leave the sultry ladies alone.
Maybe something gets lost in the translation, as often happens, but Wong may be giving us the first Eastern.
Rarely do we get to truly celebrate a movie's second time around. We should this one, though. The filmmakers really move it, move it to the next level of joyous entertainment.
Well, here's something we don't usually see at the movies. Role Models is a raucously bawdy lowbrow comedy with a brain.
Like the kangaroo that goes from a newcomer's sightseeing delight to dinner meat with the sudden crack of a rifle shot, Australia hops all over the place.

As much as I admired Benjamin Button's gimmicks, the excellent makeup and a sometimes-mesmerizing emotional journey, I just couldn't shoo away the obvious Forrest Gump similarities. Roth leans on them too strongly as a screenplay crutch.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Except for the overstated growl, which admittedly is nitpicky, Eastwood may have directed himself right back into Oscar contention.
The Unborn is so lame that even a scene where Nazi 'doctors' experiment on twin children by poking a needle in their eyeballs is more laughable than horrendous.
Not Easily Broken isn't perfect. It's a tad preachy at times. Yet it also lifts spirits with the power of emotional healing and forgiveness. Amen to that.
Banderas, sans Zorro mask but still dressed in black, goes gamely into a screenplay and film that, frankly could be better.
(Tyler) Perry, a cinematic one-man band who wrote the script, produces, directs and plays the role of a decent husband and construction worker, is still growing as a filmmaker.
I like to learn something every day. In this case I discovered a harsh truth. You can have slapstick without the comedy.
... this is a verbally poisonous comedy that rattles the sensibility cage.
When I was watching this movie the other day and rethinking my way through it now, all I can recall is Gervais and some other people. He's that good as New York dentist Dr. Bertram Pincus.
Sex and the City, which feels like a behind-numbing six episodes strung clumsily together, could be much fun in the hands of a veteran director.
Sandler can still do it when it comes to silly.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Black blasts through Po, though, and lands on the furry character's visual surface with all vocal cylinders revving.
Zalla utilizes both the dark back streets of New York and the dark nature of some humans to weave an intoxicating tale of stolen identity and pilfered emotions.
Leterrier gets his hand on this Marvel marvel at exactly the right time. Special effects have finally caught up with the imagination.
A monster movie desperately seeking a monster, M. Night Shyamalan's The Happening doesn't make sense, much less The Sixth Sense.
Surfwise spills the gripes, the frustrations and the pain onto the screen like damaged driftwood finally feeling the steadiness of shore after a long, stormy voyage at sea.
The popular deadpan comedian (Carell) is only funny about 60 percent of the time.Would you believe 50 percent?
The Love Guru pegs the silly meter in the opening scene when Myers, as Guru Pitka, breaks out in a Bollywood-style 9 to 5 hoedown while picking at a sitar.
To me, honesty like that is what heroes are made of.
Hancock is a rarity. It's an action yarn that feels like a drama and, alternately, a drama that takes our breath away with bursts of eye-popping action.
WALL-E is a technical gem, a marvel of sound design and just a little too ambitious to continuously captivate.
... when Freeman, Jolie, McAvoy and the rest get a chance, there's even some decent acting going on. It's almost as if the great Loom of Fate dropped a stitch and willed it.
Go to the movies long enough and you'll eventually find yourself rooting for a blood red, horned monster-man from hell.
(Murphy) never loses focus, although the one-dimensional nature of the script might provoke a few yawns among frequent moviegoers.
This 'Journey' appears to take place in an amusement park.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Thompson created a rebellious niche for himself in a business that more often than you might think channels its writers into conformist routine.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Dark Knight should not be remembered as the movie that took Heath Ledger out. Thanks primarily to him, it should be remembered as the movie that propelled fantasy action-thrillers to a higher level.
Tell No One is good enough to warrant not only a long run in art houses, but considerable attention for a director who dared to tweak a hugely popular novel and made it work.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: You're in for a mildly entertaining ride through lowbrow slapstick action violence. Just don't ask for a seat in the non-smoking section.
There's sex and the city (New York). But the most enjoyable girls-night-out movie of the summer deals with young, fledgling love.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's definitely not for everybody. But it's also very funny as a no-holds-barred, frat-house-party comedy.
HAL has a granddaughter? Who knew?
Lee shows his grittiness by allowing everyone to speak in their native languages. My hat's off to him for that. I'm not a fan of war films where all opposing sides speak English.
Richard Gere and Diane Lane are swathed in so much cheese in Nights in Rodanthe, this weepy story should unfold in Wisconsin instead of a tiny strip of land off the coast of North Carolina.
(Pedro) Castaneda, the male lead in Chris Eska's mesmerizing debut feature August Evening, has the kind of natural, hypnotic screen presence that cannot be taught.

Dan in Real Life isn't about real life. This is reel life, Hollywood's heightened-reality take on what might go on at a large family gathering where one woman is caught between the affections of siblings.
The swashbuckling swings from the rafters, mad races in dueling jeeps, etc. are, to get right to the point, old fedora.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Bynes gives it the old college try, though, in a watered-down combination of Legally Blonde and Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.
Even through the lens of director Phillip Noyce's sympathetic camera eye, it's impossible to keep the term 'terrorist' at bay while watching Catch a Fire.

This film's a little creaky at times, especially during long stretches of acted interviews. But the premise seems hauntingly real when President Cheney is shown delivering Bush's eulogy at a state funeral.
May the Saw mini-franchise, dulled into a bloody gore-fest bore after only three installments, rest in piece. A piece of hack-sawed-off foot here, a piece of a bludgeoned limb there.
Craig, Paul Newman's fidgety son in Road to Perdition and excellent recently opposite Toby Jones in Infamous, gives his all to one of the most iconic roles in movie history.
Let's put it this way, you will believe the Dixie Chicks are Not Ready to Make Nice.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Linklater tries to tell too much story. We don't have time to savor each valid piece of what he intends as a conscience-raising cautionary tale.
If movies could be punished, Let's Go to Prison would be sent to solitary confinement for impersonating a prison comedy.
Simply put, Déjà Vu has too much explaining to do, and even then, the ending -- which I can't discuss -- feels like a cheat.
Driving Lessons runs out of creative gas near the ridiculous end.
OK, so Wild Hogs is predictable at best. ... There are some laughs to be found.
This is a bluesy, emotional journey that casts a powerful spell.
Even though Zodiac doesn't tie itself into a tight knot of grisly finality after two hours and 40 minutes, David Fincher fans can look forward to a meticulous, intriguing case study.
For those who like the little hairs to stand at fright attention on the back of the neck while gulping popcorn down the front, though, there's a new three-foot-tall creep in town.
If Rock wants to ... spread his wings, fine. Just don't call it a comedy when it's something like I Think I Love My Wife. I don't think I love it much.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Bullock may be easing away from her kooky Miss Congeniality persona and into more substantial material at just the right time in her career.
The secret to time travel, according to The Last Mimzy, bears a computer-chip corporate logo.
This is a solid edge-of-your-seat thriller that smacks of political intrigue.
The 400 or so young kids and their parents I saw it with on a recent Sunday afternoon seemed generally underwhelmed. And I'm right there with them.
Slightly subversive but entertaining, The Host is a South Korean creature-feature import that'll get the Godzilla juices flowing again.
Like other underfunded indies ... G.I. Jesús plays more like a telenovela than a feature film.
While it's not a classic high school basketball film such as Hoosiers (1986), Believe In Me tugs at the heartstrings with vigor.
Here's to you, Meet the Robinsons. You really have taken digital 3-D animation to a somewhat ho-hum level.
I think what I like most about The Lookout is that it arrives as a single vision from conception to what we see on screen.
Iraq in Fragments ... appears to be asking a simple, but often unmentioned, question: Oh yeah, what about the people of Iraq?
From Russia with harsh love, The Italian chronicles one orphaned boy's incredible determination to reunite with his birth mother.
Bening, who took a break from acting for a few years to raise her children, is absolutely perfect as a Valium-slowed walking time bomb.
If it's not the dog of the week, this is surely a bow-wow flick without pedigree.
Robin Williams' character can't decide when to be goofy and when to play it straight, and neither can this uneven "what-if" political comedy from writer-director Barry Levinson.

Allen falls somewhere in between phoning this performance in and giving it a half-hearted try. Courteney Cox approaches her role (his love interest in a lab coat) like she'd very much like to be back on Friends.
(Casey) Affleck is adequate as the lead, although I kept wondering how much lower Buscemi could take Jim.

I felt it moved along a little too quickly, as if a tour guide with a pressing dinner reservation was determined to make all the appointed stops, but didn't linger long enough to let the impact soak in.
Over the Hedge will grow on you. It's a hoot.
As misunderstood movie monsters go, Kane's Jacob can't even get in the ring with bedeviled Quasimodo of 'The Hunchback of Notre Dame' or even Frankenstein's monster.
Ratner, right at home in the superhero world, orchestrates the frenzied final battle with a melodramatic Gone With the Wind grandeur.
Mountain Patrol, peppered with shocking revelations of just how suddenly and brutally death can come calling, has the look and feel of a documentary.

Perhaps realizing that a 14-minute theme-park ride can provide only so much story fodder, returning director Gore Verbinski merely ramps everything to a higher level, right down to Depp's signature saunter.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Spirited and somewhat bittersweet, Superman Returns remains a fascinating and very entertaining ride most of the way %u2014 though it's probably at least 20 minutes too long for optimum interest.
Click goes clunk when the screenwriters lather on the sentiment too thick
A warning light came on in my head when I noticed that Cars has more credited screenwriters (six) than many cars have pistons (four).
A carjacking leads to violence, revenge and antiheroes impossible to root for in Waist Deep, an urban gangster crime-thriller.

Sandra Bullock and Keanu Reeves, two actors with talent I admire, launched their careers (at least as movie stars) on a runaway bus (Speed) in 1994. They appear to be throwing themselves under one here.
Little Man, featuring an adult little person posing as a toddler to steal a huge diamond, spits up a few lowbrow belly laughs. But not enough to go 'goo-goo, gaga' over.
I haven't seen it in the movie ads yet, but Brian 'Kato' Kaelin (O.J. Simpson's infamous houseguest) is sure to proclaim You, Me and Dupree 'the best film of the year.'
The school is like none you've seen on screen before. Mary Katherine Gallagher would 'love, love, LOVE!' it, as do I.
This effort, while a failure, is an artsy, noble one. Scanning optimistically, an innovator can learn and move forward from that.
Veteran filmmaker Ivan Reitman (Ghostbusters, Dave) almost pulls off this offbeat comic romance. But not quite.

The director's job is to cast the best available talent in each key role. Shyamalan has done that with Giamatti, Balaban and Jeffrey Wright (as a crossword-puzzle lover). But he took this audience member out of the story by putting himself in.
If you've ever been freaked out by that run-down gothic-looking house down at the end of the block, you must see Monster House. If not, go anyway.
For once, Farrell's bad-boy swagger fits nicely into a character. None of that silly Alexander blond-haired posing this time.
Scoop manages some decent moments of frivolity. Allen can still play a bumbling goof when he puts his mind to it.
You'll likely step a little more carefully around an anthill after going on the delightful animated journey The Ant Bully.
Don't die, just go away. ... Where's John Hughes when we need him?
In an amazing turnabout ... Stone fills the screen with a film from the heart instead of his conspiracy-filled mind.
Pulse isn't awful. It's just an uninspired fright-fest with ghouls we've seen before and not enough creative style to make us forget that fact.

Jones, a little-known character actor taking a major leap in name recognition with one of the finest performances of the year, could easily make it back-to-back Oscar nominations for Capote as a character.
We were done in the first five minutes.
God sends down a river of blood, swarming locusts and two-time Academy Award winner Hilary Swank. Guess which one's slumming in a supernatural thriller?
Hear ye, hear ye. Films don't always have to be revolutionary slice-of-life cinematic art. Sometimes they can just be cheesy, nonsensical fun. Like Perfect Stranger.
I got a familiar gut feeling: There is this year's Oscar-winning best-actress performance.
Once captures the intoxicating one-two punch of loving music and falling in love better than any movie since Tender Mercies and The Buddy Holly Story (1978).
When the humans slow things down, and they do, Bay cranks up the Gobots (excuse me, Transformers) for earth-shattering battles that pound the ground mightily ...

Radcliffe appears game enough to continue in the iconic role he has grown up with. So do Watson and Grint, although the exuberant let's-put-on-a-show sparkle of youth has, sadly, drained from all three.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: With the exception of ramming my head into a brick wall, then backing up and repeating the exercise, I can't think of anything I'd rather not be doing on a Friday afternoon.
Like the teaching profession, Chalk is at times tedious and rewarding.
Ben Kingsley, or Sir Ben as he's called on the other side of the Atlantic, is an odd choice to play a hard-drinking Polish hit man from Buffalo, N.Y.
Napoleon without the creative dynamite
Jason Bourne, like the action-thriller movie franchise he fronts, has grown weary of the chase.
Despite pulsating to a hot, hot, hot salsa beat, El Cantante is often a mess, mess, mess.
Cheadle (in an Afro wig and sideburns)and Ejiofor are good enough to merit Oscar consideration, but only as a tag-team.
Golden Door belongs to(Vincenzo) Amato (Respiro). He makes this tale of woe and wonderment the charmer it turns out to be.
Too bad, but this ambitious, scratched and weathered venture never manages a real death grip on the senses.
Lucky for us, the verbiage sparkles with wit and preposterousness just close enough to reality to make us grind our teeth in the agony of recognition. D'oh, I mean to make us laugh.
Harry Potter for older teens and adults, that's the best way to describe the fantastic fantasy ride that is Stardust.
You might be a little surprised or at least amused when the caustic, tired, joyous, frantic roller coaster stops.
Think of this scenario as a smart, witty, well-acted romance novel that has sprung to life on the big screen with some restraint and a decent amount of dignity.

I like the fact that this one-note comedy -- OK, two: sex and booze -- makes no pretense of being anything other than a titillation-entertainment ride for the young and those who still remember how to think that way.

Lots of text messaging under pressure and swapping slimy, alien-infected spittle. I'm thinking all the scientists really need to control the latest wave of mind-bogglers from outer space are some strategically placed spittoons.
Warm and fuzzy despite its frigid locale, Arctic Tale is the huggable nature film many people expected from March of the Penguins, but didn't get.
Although it's not a French parlor farce, My Best Friend appears headed that way at times. Then it has the courage to ride a bittersweet wave to something more meaningful.
Solely as a magical mystery tour of sights, sounds and surrealism, however, it's a unique animated blast to the senses.
Fogler resembles a hybrid of the late John Belushi and 'Superbad' co-writer and co-star Seth Rogen, with many of the funny parts missing, or at least muted.
With nothing much left to do in its third installment, Resident Evil: Extinction heads for Alfred Hitchcock territory and gives us The Birds.

Haggis' camera hovers over Jones' craggy face as if it were the lunar lander looking for a smooth spot to land. There is no virgin terrain on Jones' weathered face, just creased landscape that could be headed for another well-deserved Oscar nomination.
A note to Oscar: You haven't noticed yet, but there's this guy up in Canada named Cronenberg.
Expect Chan and Tucker to bust it up with a steady array of bad guys, just as they've done before. And before.
By spitting out 30 minutes of unnecessary middle, Ratatouille could have come out of the oven a magnificent feast instead of a pedestrian meal for the masses.
It's just a shame Danes and the others are working with one arm tied behind them, so to speak, due to a lack of inspired material.
Willis may be beyond what some consider an action star's prime. Yet like Clint Eastwood in the drama arena, he just keeps going out there and getting it done at a high level.
Caruso ... almost lets this one wander out of control in horror mode near the end. He reins it back in just in time, though.
I think they go a little gun crazy in the final reel. Bullets shot from the imagination of these guys are fun. Zombies were merely funnier.
I like the fact that Fracture is a courtroom thriller that doesn't spend long, grueling scenes in a stuffy courtroom.
The rats are huddled in a neat little herd, obviously awaiting the next signal from a Hollywood rat wrangler. That's horrifying on a whole different level.
Kasdan, perhaps living out some of his own angst through Brody's befuddled-writer character, knows how to explore the inner workings of human nature.
(Sam) Raimi, otherwise near-perfect in transitioning his once spider-bitten hero from Marvel Comic book to movie screen, has given in to overkill and over-thrill.
This is a film that dares to look at faith from a fresh perspective. The fact that the film is back in theaters at all is a near-miracle.
Black Book will drive home the struggles of world war underground resistance. But as my colleague said, you will snicker a little.
White, who shows promise as a director willing to steer us in unexpected directions, holds the comic moments on a pretty tight leash.
Pardon the pun, but Moore has now become as big, if not bigger, than the issues he takes on.
Zombies aren't even really zombies any more. They're enraged virus victims who move extremely fast. The blood lust remains, but they appear to be hitting the Red Bull trough as well.
It may not be good news for casting agents and some directors, but Lohan is the real deal. She can act.
After cringing through Son of the Mask in 2005, I was convinced that trying to be funny could not get any worse for Jamie Kennedy. ... I was wrong that things couldn't get worse.
The Ex is a sitcom posing as a feature film.
Just two years ago Jolie swapped flying bullets and heated saliva with Brad Pitt in the crowd-pleasing Mr. & Mrs. Smith.
Cusack, a talented everyman but not quite a slick leading-man type, spends much of his time alone, battling the elements as it were.
Lord, I apologize, but Larry the Cable Guy just can't seem to get 'er done in a feature film.
(Emma)Roberts, Julia Roberts' niece and bad boy Eric's daughter, packs an efficient sleuth kit as the title character.
Rise of the Silver Surfer is impressively mounted and bursting with playful, spectacular special effects.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: If Shadyac and Oedekerk opt to take on this subject thrice, let's hope for more comic intervention, divine or otherwise.
While the Las Vegas hold 'em tables provide the backdrop, this film revolves around human emotions.
Gavin Hood, adapting playwright Athol Fugard's 1980 novel, sweeps us out of our comfy seats and drops us into the stark realities of an impoverished world ruled by those most bold and ruthless.
Oh brother, where art thou politically?
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The only place the camera doesn't go is the brewery. That's where the monks bottle their world famous Chartreuse liqueur, which sustains them financially.
(Gore)Verbinski and (Johnny)Depp, saving the best for a stupendous effects-enhanced final (don't count on it) battle, really dock this franchise with a flourish.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The appeal, I suppose, is that some really awful stuff is unfolding up there on the screen and not to us.
Offers mainstream America a look at Shakur's immense talent and the ever-expanding world of hip-hop music.
When it comes to pop-music icons, Neil Young is the full package.
Hustle & Flow uses its street smarts to show that dreams come in all shapes and sizes and that their realization sometimes is preceded by nightmares.
A treasure for baby-boomer rockers and a miniature history lesson for younger music fans.
Proof...verifies that quality filmmaking triumphs over tabloid gossip.
Its inability to muster more laughs than groans will have even Schneider's diehard fans longing for the merely awful Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo.
The most remarkable aspect of this is how rubbish the CGI effects are -I mean, this is Peter Jackson, for goodness' sake!
The trademark Loony Toon-lite slapstick undeniably compensates for a bitty, unmemorable plot that stampedes along like a mammoth through chewing gum.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Those anticipating crackling, Heat-style cat-and-mouse Al Pacino/Robert de Niro face-offs will be left like disappointed kittens without the cream.
An intimate, shoddily shot doc.
movie_title: Am I Black Enough for You? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Big on yawns and short on screams, no cliché is left unharvested.

More Life Of Grime than CSI, Sunshine Cleaning is tonally a bit messy, the characters over-coloured and the whole 'they need to clean up their own life' theme is over-tidy. But it's good to see a chick flick with guts, even if they're all over the carpet.

Fundamentally Ramis plays it way too safe with the religious material. Think less Life Of Brian than a teacher trying to jolly up the parables at Hebrew school - it still beats being smited by a plague of frogs.
Sexy and freewheeling, if frustratingly slight, it never hits the emotional back of the net in the manner of Looking For Eric but the lead actors' charisma keeps you merrily bouncing along.
Brutal in its psychological honesty, Antichrist is slashed through with von Trier's love of teasing, titillating, revolting and disturbing the viewer, as well as making them laugh.

Despite some jolly, off-the-wall moments the comedy becomes increasingly desperate, relying on those old staples of fruity old relations, poodle-y pets in peril, 1980s pop dance offs and amusing, over-sexed foreigners.
A cracking, suspenseful watch that has a well-turned knack for the tragic-comic.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The emerging mother/daughter separation dynamic pushes all the expected emotional buttons but ultimately reduces potentially fascinating, multi-layered material into a by-numbers daytime telly weepie.
This stylish, if narratively flimsy biopic of French fashion designer Gabrielle 'Coco' Chanel truly sparkles in one respect only: the star quality of Audrey 'Amélie' Tautou.
Guaranteed non-stop, gung-ho action plugged directly into your synapses.
A good-natured, hit-and-miss mess, further muddied by some seriously inappropriate humour.

Director Scott is, as usual, way more into blowing stuff up than a moral cat-and-mouse game. Any hint of depth sends him zooming into yet another flashily pointless 'woo woo' motorbike chase, destroying the masterful two-hander tension.
What? Who? And, most pertinently, why? The greatest mystery of this gloriously preposterous B-movie psychodrama is the casting.
Slightly overrated and over here, this slick French thriller may not be the crime classic it's touted as, but it's still a gripping, action-driven portrait of the last of France's great gangsters.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An utterly charming love story between two quirky, vulnerable loners? A vomitous fairy-cake concoction of nursery rhyme tweeness? It's all certainly rather less Rain Man, and more Drizzle Boy.

Who was shooting who and why? No idea! I didn't care! Because there was loads of constantly exploding stuff. Expect no more, and you'll be reasonably satisfied by this least demanding of summer blockbusters.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)
