movie_review_blurb: Scoff-inducing twist aside, this is an uncannily astute and unnerving family psychodrama, over-garnished by final-act splatter.
It's actually hard to tell who's less likeable in this ugly, unfunnily vulgar battle of the sexes: Heigl's prim control freak or Butler's dim sexist.
This oddly toned high-school flick may boast less of the X-Factor but it's all the more interesting for its raggedy edges.
A painfully prolonged saccharine gunk tank, guaranteed to displease all ages.
As vibrantly coloured and in-your-face visceral as you'd expect: a woozy, punch-out shot makes you feel like it's your own head hitting the dirt.
This isn't the fully marshmallow-basted turkey it seems at first glance. However, it barely scratches the surface of Audrey Niffenegger's superior beach read.

There's the odd breathtakingly composed shot, chilling scenario and exquisitely poignant turn from the overpopulated cast but the sombrely indulgent pacing betrays the fact that acclaimed director Andrzej Wajda is now aged 83.

The tone lurches jerkily from ersatz 1960s caper to shouty histrionic tragedy, while Con O'Neill can't quite pull off Meek's magnetic personality, attractive as it was repellent. But it sure beats The Boat That Rocked.

The insurmountable problem is the two-and-a-half-hour (argh!) running time, during which the minuscule central conflict is bulked out by tedious 'put the lost key thing into the other gizmo thing' cross-plots.
A wee-inducingly funny bromance.

Wondrous, wow-inducing marvels - seal calls that sound weirdly like Pink Floyd; rare glimpses into the eerily alien underwater universe of exquisite ice cathedrals - uplift the soul as Herzog explores his pet obsessions.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Interesting and disturbing, it's one most will love or loathe - probably the latter.

Writer/director Eran Creevy's self-described 'urban thriller' is a delightful surprise, then: a buddy movie genuinely more interested in subtle, character-driven storytelling than cheap, gangster-flick bling.

It's a tight, intimate drama. Like Bourne, this enthrallingly twisted plot starts - and stays - on the run but Brit director Kevin Macdonald guns for characterisation and intelligent 'state of the world' musing over expensively exploding helicopters.
The Unremarkable might be a better title for this creakily constructed but enjoyable enough scary movie.
It's Jackman's bulging charisma that keeps this testosterone-powered action blockbuster racing along.
While life (and death) lessons are duly learned, this isn't quite the smother-me-with-a-saccharine pillow experience it promised to be.
It's pleasingly impossible to describe the ominously beautiful atmosphere that haunts this bold and baffling Brit debut.

Given Bana's baddie is about as threatening as a scatter cushion and the plot is arm-chewingly repetitive, what will appeal most to bemused non-fans is that while the Star Wars prequels disappeared up their own mythologies, Star Trek is a right giggle.
Skittering up goosebumps of wonderment at every turn, this latest spooky stop motion from director Henry Selick is a visual masterpiece - yet misses that magic ingredient: a heart.
It's fair to say if Twilight heart-throb Robert Pattinson didn't star here as the young Salvador Dalí, this almost perversely unilluminating biopic would never have troubled the light of day.

With barely a waft of plot, what glides you along is Hampton's delightfully barbed dialogue and the gorgeous backdrops. But if Dangerous Liaisons was vintage champagne, this is gluggable supermarket cava.
At a bum-numbing two-and-a-half hours, you need more. You may have seen war through the eyes of Quentin Tarantino - but there's nowt going on behind them.

One star is maybe harsh but Indiana Jones this most definitely ain't. It's not even Scooby Doo. Forget science versus faith - at well over two hours the only gripping conflict here is tedium versus tosh.
This one's a cut above, despite the sellout ending, thanks to its vivid capturing of New York's hustle and flow, and surprisingly deep-rooted turns by the perfectly matched Howard and Tatum.
A sequel that's actually better than the original? Get out of here.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: One for shoe-gazing musos with a guilty desire to (vicariously) stick the boot in.
Ignore the drippy sounding title. This snappy French psycho-drama will transfix your attention like a stiletto heel skewering a ciggie butt.
movie_title: L'Empreinte de l'ange (Mark of an Angel) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Friday The 13th meets St Trinian's in a jolly gory product that finally proves we Brits can make slick, silly high-school slashers too.
There's little time to get bored, and you get the feeling this film knows it's ridiculous.
Maybe not one for all the family but this fairground ghost train will drag you to Hell kicking and screaming - with laughter.
This masterfully pitched exercise in sombre revelation may frustrate sports fans looking for an easy hit.
A bit like The Full Monty with football, this is finally an art house film by and for 'the people' that 'the people' might actually want to see.
Director John Woo belatedly hits his stride, socking the one-dimensional epic to you with trademark 'woo hoo!' style.
Skimming lightly over graphs and in-depth investigation in favour of pretty shots of sunset-dappled seas, it lacks the smack of hard facts.
This glossily dumbed-down remake is little more than sloppy, multiplex-aimed torture porn dribbled with pantie shots.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Loop-the-looping big themes such as mortality, infidelity and impotence, this is an hilarious, intellectual roller-coaster ride you'll rush to take again.

Provocative, unflinching and stripped of anything approaching a consoling music soundtrack, it's a must for fans of challenging, A+ intelligent cinema desperately seeking the antithesis of High School Musical.
[A] fantastically zany if draggingly storyless story.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Wises are cracked and touching coming-of-age lessons learned - think Nick And Norah's Infinite Playlist with a more rubbish soundtrack.
It's barely scary, but it's a treat for every boy (or girl) who'd hack off their right arm to hear Megan Fox purr: 'You've given me such a wettie.'

Emmerich confidently controls his marathon; teasing you with a street crack here, a supermarket tremor there, before going for all-out, balls-to-the -all world destruction. Effects truly don't get more special than this.

[Daniel Barber's] bludgeon-you-over-the-head social commentary and borderline fascistic torture porn is thankfully offset by some remarkably sensitive camera work, plus a tear-jerking performance from the 76-year-old Caine.
Damon's rarely been better as a seemingly normal guy who you never really get a handle on, but the light-toned narrative could certainly be snappier.

A cracking British character cast, an intriguing angle on World War II and scrummy frocks can't compensate for what's highly coloured tosh, whose every 'twist' is more heavily signposted than roadworks on the M25.
Paul King's remarkable comedy debut is a dazzlingly unique creation, light years ahead of your bog-standard TV series spin-off.
Think Queer As Folk but less raunchy and rather more rubbish.
This charmingly different biopic is a quality treat.

Sparkly, if unmemorable, its unusually old-fashioned charm makes Me And Orson Welles more like something Efron's army of tiny, squealing fans would take their mums to - rather than the other way around.
What would have been perfection at one hour is still a bravely different Christmas movie, one destined to be a cult classic for generations to come.
Skin-crawling moments aside, this glossy US studio movie is surprisingly less about splatter than moments of hard-hitting moral confrontation.
This is multiplex fodder for the (very) undemanding: they should give this kind of cinematic junk food away free with the popcorn.
Bright Star is at once sublimely swoonsome yet marvellously down to Earth.
This atmospheric indie made by Argentine writer/director Alexis Dos Santos is fun and quietly irreverent but it's not hugely romantic.
It's the psychology of this unlikely situation that makes this edgy buddy flick so fascinating and funny. Entirely ad-libbed, it's The Hangover with a brain.
The title may be a minger, but this second jolly helping of the resurrected British boarding school franchise packs some quality titters.
movie_title: St Trinian's II: The Legend of Fritton's Gold (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An unforgettable love story, an absorbing road movie, a searing examination of people pushed to the very limits and an ultimately uplifting celebration of the human spirit.
A stilted, yet-another-British-gangster thriller - a remarkable disappointment given its pukka cast.
This masterfully told study in understatement is a real grower.
A brilliantly astute twist on the romcom that sparkles with spiky one-liners and outstanding performances.
A powerful watch that tellingly melts away to nothing as the credits roll.
Even with a hit-and-run running time of under 90 minutes, this solid, low-tension actioner outstays its welcome.
Shot like a bad episode of Spooks with its scenes set on random shuffle, the plot of this global pudding is utterly incomprehensible, the dialogue the worst kind of chopsocky silliness.
A burst of feel-good sunshine in a grey January.
Passionately told with bucketloads of compassion, this is a film that'll have you moaning 'no, no, no!'
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A silly remake of the 1985 BBC TV series, this features the sort of tough-guy dialogue not growled since Arnie bowed out of cinema, eg: 'The suspect's armed and dangerous.'
It's truly unlike anything you've seen before. Don your 3D specs and you're instantly so sucked into the world of Avatar you pay zero attention to the plot - then realise hey, that's no loss.
This lump of telly melodrama is basically a bland, off-puttingly shouty sermon in film's clothing.
There's no warmth from these spooky, human-modelled digitised automatons, who glide about like all-night trance festival-goers the morning after.
Hornby is more interested in the confrontation of self cocooning fantasy with cold reality, of learning to grow up and take responsibility for your life, whatever your age.
Another movie spoof so lame the kindest thing one could do is shoot it and put it - and us - out of our collective misery.
Pedro Almodóvar's visually sumptuous feature will please but not wow his fans, since it retreads familiar waters to unremarkable effect.
They lazily let the effects do most of the hard work in this 'ain't broke' scenario.
This is a kind of cuddly bromance take on Scorsese's The King Of Comedy, in which sentimentality balances bleakness without toppling into schmaltz.

Director Kathryn Bigelow brilliantly surfs a line between challenging, realistic grit and Hollywood thrills, her gripping buddy movie all the more exciting for not blindly following the orders of most big action flicks.
It boasts all the analytical depth of a bullet graze but it's still a grippingly groovy watch.
District 9 socks you with humour, gore and fast-paced action and it never feels worthy, while delivering an unexpectedly touching reflection on man's inhumanity to man.

Andrzej Jakimowski's intimate if slightly disjointed tale of dreams abandoned, connections not made and things not said evokes such a timeless sense of sun-drenched, small-town life, even non-Poles will feel nostalgic.

Why not just make a fictional film? Conflating these seemingly mocked-up scenarios with non-actors and their genuine experiences (eg the shoots for porn magazines) just results in an unsatisfying mess.
This raw, eccentric documentary is both hugely entertaining and 'can do' inspirational.

Visually striking but never stylised, it's simply astonishing to find a film that's such a hard-hitting smack in the mouth, yet, at the same time, a marvel of such fragile, natural beauty. Best British film of the year? You bet.
Comfort viewing for credit-crunch times, this over-long movie is cosy, bland, a bit sugary and totally undemanding. The cinematic equivalent of sticking your brain inside a warm oven.
Too dark for littl'uns, too hectic and cutesy for adults, it's pretty much guaranteed to please no one.

Glimpsing the emotional chinks in Wintour's armour makes this a fascinating watch as much as the to-die-for frocks, XXL personalities and hilarious fashionista nonsense intoned like papal decree. Eg: 'Jackets are the new coats.'
'Lame!' would be a better title for this utterly unmemorable remake of Alan Parker's edgier, darker, remarkably fresh 1980 multi-Oscar-winner.
Set your brain to standby and you'll just about suck up this glossy dollop of Total Recall-lite.
With endless widescreen panoramas of birds in flight, Disney's latest nature doc looks like an expensive British Airways advert.
Go in with (very) low expectations and they may just be surpassed.
Think Carry On without the sophisticated humour or enlightened views on foreign stereotyping.
Pixar's tenth movie is undoubtedly a work of art but what truly makes it glow is that it's a timeless story about love and has obviously been made with tons of the stuff.
This chuckle-inducing, improvised collaboration between Considine and director/mate Shane Meadows feels more like a lark than a feature movie but it's got a serious motive.
The narrative suffers from a recurrent limp but there are memorable high notes, namely a genius cameo by the ever marvellous Bill Murray as himself.
For a movie that champions the importance of storytelling, that is, ironically, its limpest department.
The déjà vu plot loop-the-loops back on itself till it sends you right round the twist.
As intelligent as it is blackly humorous, visually elegant, full-bloodedly erotic and a good half-hour too long.
Less Roald Dahl, more The Royal Tenenbaums with a tail and whiskers. Visually, as you'd expect from Anderson, it's gorgeous.
Neatly observed and a right giggle.

It's an extra remarkable triumph that The Thick Of It, Armando Iannucci's massively acclaimed political satire, explodes on to the big screen without sacrificing a jot of its blistering, hand-held, outrageously well-scripted glory.
You'll wish the once-talented Myers had merely rested on his laurels rather than pooping into them.
There are gripping moments of tough, muscular moral tension, mainly when Isaacs steps in, but these are dissipated by occasionally cringeworthy dialogue and a limply executed bourgeois subtext.
This isn't the truffle box of Brit thesps you'd imagine; instead, the main star is Andrew Davies's nuanced, if awkwardly paced script.
Don't get excited by the saucy title of this offbeat US indie. What sounds like an X-rated skin flick is in fact an indulgent, emotionally ersatz 'unusual fairytale' of a lonely young woman.
Bafflingly, this film leaves you not knowing whether to kill yourself, cry, walk out or laugh.
And though 14-year-old Saoirse Ronan (Oscar-nominated for Atonement) shines as the city's saviour, even she can't light a path through a suspenseless plot seemingly attacked by hungry moths.
It's as unsentimental as it is understated and only afterwards do you realise how remarkable it is to find a mafia film that neither over-grits nor over-glams its underworld.
But High Tension director Alexandre Aja's disappointingly low-tension Hollywood studio remake is a pale reflection of its Korean original.

The ending is predictably feel-good - if it takes way too long coming - but the female-penned script keeps you perky with some surprisingly surreal flashes... such as: 'The eyes are like the nipples of the face.'
Mutant Chronicles is as atrocious as its terrible title suggests - but one redemptive aspect to this based-on- a-role-play-game snooze-fest is its ambitious visual flair.
Deceptively dark for all its lightness, Coen haters will be infuriated by a stylish conceit that perversely sets out not to amount to a hill of beans.
Under-tens are unlikely to be the only ones wondering what's going on; the story is an over-brainstormed botch job.
A decent US ensemble cast includes regulars from Curb Your Enthusiasm and, though the pacing is too slack, some silly one-liners help to make up for it.
That not all of them do sadly lends a much-needed emotional depth to a doc that, odd beautiful moments aside, can feel like a solid reality TV hour stretched out to 108 minutes. Bring hankies.
This comedy is gunning to do for glossy magazines what The Devil Wears Prada did for fashion - and ends up shooting itself in the hand-stitched loafers.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This glittery Disney product may boast the biggest, fastest advance sales in movie history but it remains largely a mystery to those of us with an age in double figures.

The story is far-fetched and exploitative and the awkward dialogue is frequently laughable. But committed acting, cast chemistry and the odd touching moment just about save you from checking whether this was actually produced by Bernard Matthews.

Reminiscent of early Jackie Chan flicks, an action-packed, pick-and-mix of punch-ups include a cheeky tribute to Lee's legendary icehouse scene in The Big Boss, culminating in a spectacular multi-storey jaw-dropper.
An 'interesting' more than enjoyably escapist entry to the 007 cannon.
Achieving truth through beauty, Hunger is an art movie in the deepest sense.
Terence Davies's first film in eight years is a beauty.
A natty satire on imperialism and très visually stylish to boot, it constantly keeps you tickled with crazy one-liners and silly visual gags.
movie_title: OSS 117: Le Caire Nid d'Espions (OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A quirky romcom, bonkers in the way only Japanese movies can be.
But although there's the odd, inspired shock gag, most of the laughs are lazy and the predictable romcom ending takes way too long to arrive.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: What's surprising is that such a heavyweight combo of Crowe, DiCaprio and Scott would waste their collective gravitas on something so light. Action and acting are both solid but there's no deeper human or political dimension to justify the running time.
It's a confused compromise between 'seeing the real person' parable, no-fun sci-fi and self-realisation drama that's basically The Day Of The Triffids minus the killer plants.

Wonderfully acted if wildly flawed, this a weirdly funny, ultimately uplifting ensemble comedy drama about having the courage to be a real person and love another: you won't know whether to split your sides or your wrists.
By portraying conflict via cartoon, Ari Folman's remarkable animated documentary reloads the genre's impact.
Fancy a good bit of foreign art house of a Saturday night? You've found your pick of the week.
Warm and engaging, this has its cutesy moments and crazy Van Gogh-inspired time-travel fantasy visuals but remains appealingly grounded in relatable, sublimated adolescent fears of growing up.
movie_title: The Girl Who Leapt Through Time (2007)

movie_review_blurb: For all its half-hearted attempts to trip expectation, Hunt's adaptation of Elinor Lipman's novel is ultimately a romcom wherein themes of adoption and betrayal come with too much sensitive, careworn soul-searching.
A game of good, solid passes that emotionally fail to hit the back of the net.
As clunky as it is emotionally unconvincing.
Focusing on the simple folk normally relegated to the background of the world stage, this warm comedy has a gentle Life Of Brian flavour and its own shrewd sense of enterprise.
movie_title: El Baño del Papa (The Pope's Toilet) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Tapping into parental abandonment issues, it's an occasionally touching, if frustratingly one-note drama - played, relentlessly, on a tinkly-sad piano.
Deftly balancing honesty, poignancy, sensationalism and humour, it's a palm-sweating story - and the excitable Petit is a born storyteller.
The only truly memorable element is Billy Connolly, who pops up rather desperately as a self-castrated paedophile psychic priest. Enough now.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Overlong and overcrowded, this tired threequel soon has you yawning. John Hannah's cry: 'Die, you mummy b******s, die!' is the only line to raise a cheer.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Directed by and starring Stephen Chow of Kung Fu Hustle fame, it's definitely one only for the kiddies - those who are prepared to read subtitles. Should be a smash hit, then.
Any magic is instantly dispelled by the dead hand of a tirelessly pouting Zeta-Jones, whose slap boasts more layers than her talent.

McDormand brings a Chaplinesque pathos to this snappy period comedy. Fabulous frocks, tasty men, female bonding, art deco apartments to die for; it's like Sex And The City set in 1930s London. I could have happily watched it for hours...
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: For horrified parents, Donny Osmond's cameo is - scarily - the sole lifebelt in a truly desperate mess of unamusing plot randomness, which runs from sky-diving to high-IQ pigs.
It's narrated with ear-tearing pretentiousness by snapper Edo Bertoglio, primarily as an attempt to get over his past - he should have concentrated on getting over himself.
An uninspired comedy that runs the full gamut from characters being punched in the groin/face to being shot in the face/groin, until everything culminates in an expensively pointless action finale.
Funny, raw and gentle, bearing national identity issues with enviable lightness, it's essentially a beautiful piece of black and white observation, buffed from many hours of improv.
Funny as it is watching balding middle-aged men clowning like eight-year-olds - particularly when it involves Ferrell man-crying - it soon starts to grow old when that's all the script has to offer.
The direction is unlikeably murky and unfocused but this is more dope than wack - and a guaranteed four-star movie if you're already stoned yourself.
A sci-fi actioner that sees bald hero Vin Diesel back stomping around the future like a small, gun-toting penis.
A good scary movie retells a creaky story in a manner that terrifies you afresh. All this has is Tyler trembling like a wet-lipped goldfish in a performance you could peg out to drip dry. Run away.
Light radiates intensely from Reha Erdem's glowing enigma, a spiritual yet earthy meditation on the passing of time that proves quietly fruitful.
But his gift for wicked smash/grab visuals and larky, on-der-money one-liners just about compensates for all his gratingly puerile posing.
You'll find yourself less fixated on inner turmoil than whether you could feasibly slip a cocktail sausage between her perma-pouting lips.
Proof that Cage will sign up to anything that involves a mad hair weave and a motorbike.

The flashback structure adds nothing but length to an already awkward mix of humanist-socialist parable and gently halting love story that's been sat on a shelf since 2005. But even so, it's a surprisingly sweet little treat.
It's the latest proof that, when it comes to scary movies at least, the British film industry is alive and screaming.
A disturbing, bleak, multilayered mystery that will not just worm under your flesh but also wriggle inside your nightmares.
No sooner did the woeful Step Brothers suggest Judd Apatow's comedy empire was starting to spread itself thinner than a banana skin under an anvil, he strikes back with this almost-classic.
A ghastly Sex And The City knock-off guaranteed to make its chick-flick audience storm angrily out in search of the next Rambo movie.

You may think I'm being a spoilsport but I'm doing you a favour by lowering your expectations. Get the beers in first and Tom Cruise jive-dancing to T-Pain's Lo in a hairy fat suit may well be the funniest thing you've seen that evening.

The sensational material is episodic and gut-wrenchingly affecting but Eastwood keeps a strong hand on it, even if it often feels like a big-bucks version of a daytime TV drama. The Oscar race starts here.

It's true that he, along with a load of risqué sexual chuckles and endearingly oddball plot-quirks, can't quite keep up the comic momentum but it's still a highly pleasing man-date movie that will tickle your girlfriend's fancy too.
A rewarding and redemptive story where money is a meagre substitute for human sympathy and love.
Robert De Niro is thankfully back in 'funny' mode for this enjoyable, if oddly pointless, Hollywood-eatsitself comedy.
This glossy bioflick of late hip hop legend Christopher 'The Notorious BIG' Wallace - aka Biggie Smalls, or 'Chrissy-poo' to his momma - is unlikely to trouble the Academy.
Like an (even) less amusing Mr Bean, Martin now looks just that bit too old and creepy to be gurning through this predictable gamut of feeble slapstick.
Are you under 11, love dogs and think the only thing funnier than someone stepping in poo is someone stepping in it again? Boy, you've hit the jackpot!
Forget that overhyped Slumdog Millionaire - THIS is the feel-good film of the year.
Dripping with drink/drugs/infidelity melodrama: it's almost impossible not to make a compelling movie out of this material, but somehow writer/director Darnell Martin manages.
The result, a second story-less mumble in the jungle, is so exhaustingly over-researched it can't see the wood for the trees - and, believe me, one thing you'll not feel short-changed over is trees.
A cheap'n'cheerless Legally Blonde meets The Devil Wears Prada knock-off, this raises the odd girlie giggle but mainly made me want to claw my own face off.

Directed by as well as starring Eastwood, this is the expected well-tooled, well-produced machine, effortlessly bringing into play big themes of age, race, religion, death, war, vengeance and cultural identity with humour, tension and pathos.
What emerges is a high-school movie that is remarkably enthralling and complex. A quietly outstanding microcosm of modern society that's anything but ABC.
You have to applaud the glittering visual assurance of Brit writer/director Gerald McMorrow's feature debut, even as your ears curl at his script's adolescent whiffle.
The title of the sleekly professional The International sounds off-puttingly more like a corporate hotel than a thriller and the first half proves just as blandly businesslike.

What's happened to Renée Zellweger's face in this film? Sadly, it's the only thing new about this wait-and-rent-it romcom, leaving one ample time to ponder why she now resembles an over-boiled Cabbage Patch doll.
Suspense-free, humour-free, flavour-free yet scarily consumable cinema wherein a cheap-meat cast are skewered with the same dispiriting efficiency as a platter of cold tofu canapés.
Kabbalah meets The Exorcist in this hotchpotch hokum of vengeful ghosts, killer children, crazy old psychic ladies and supernatural Nazi experimentation.
Enjoyable, confidently executed and well-played, though there may be more than a touch of the Tony Blairs about Sheen's Clough.
This film by director Michael Winterbottom has one outstanding element: his gently naturalistic capturing of family dynamics.
If you feel director James Toback, Tyson's friend of 23 years, occasionally pussyfoots around his ear-chewing subject, frankly who could blame him?
An experience akin to watching Titanic but longer and with fewer jokes.
Chock full of amazing weather-beaten faces, it's warmly nostalgic without stooping to cheap sentiment and certainly less miserablist than a summary may suggest.
movie_title: Profils Paysans: la Vie Moderne (Modern Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's the predictable, colourful mix of kiddie-aimed slapstick and wise-cracking adult-aimed one-liners, although for once the life lessons are pleasingly underplayed.
Snappily edited and intercut with hilariously snide subtitles, this may be preaching to the converted but there's an ark-load of laughs.
Super-colourful, super-bouncy and as much of a giggle as a tickle fight in a balloon factory.

Boasting good comic delivery and a surprising ability to jerk the tears, Efron proves he's more than a pretty face, though the fact he's already topless in scene one shows the studio knows which way its bread is buttered.
The tension occasionally grips but the brutal torture scenes ensure it's unlikely to pull in a wide audience.
The dire plot is, of course, mere tarmac to the chases - so why are these so poorly choreographed? Fast & Furious? Ha. More like Slow & Sleep-inducing.
As vampire movies go this touches the cloak hem of masterpiece.
Even Cage's hair weave is less amusing than usual, while a so-bad-it's-boring plot speeds along with all the urgency of a snail setting out for a potter about the garden.
Hard to tell if Woody's schoolboyish crush on Spain (Gaudí! Miro! Flamenco!) rivals his one on Johansson but both are equally embarrassing.
Luminescent and transporting, this is a fairy tale you'll want to live inside - just not one you'll want to sit through for 103 minutes.
As its absurdly macho title hints, this action film is on a mission: not to delight or beguile so much as to club you over the head.
It feels like a long slog toward a half-baked ending that wants to have its sugary Christmas cake and eat it.
A game of three halves, this jogs well into at least 30 minutes of extra time, while the screenplay so oozes with earnestness you'll be wiping the inspiration off your face.

The biggest draw here isn't the sub-sitcom schtick but the super-hi-definition CGI panoramas - make sure you see this in Imax, where your eyeballs have enough room to roam over the impressive wide vista bits.
All zippy choreography and gleaming bodywork (mainly Statham's), producer/writer Luc Besson's cartoonish sequel has a no-brain, 'job done' feel but totally delivers pedal-to-the-metal action.
This gutsy doc, directed by the producers of Bowling For Columbine, has a raw, grass-roots perspective that makes the social devastation sink in afresh.
Not only is it 20th Century Fox's first 'carbon neutral' production but its Earth-destroying special effects have less impact than a fart in a thunderstorm.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This quaint but clumsy adaptation muddles along with increasingly plot-holed confusion like some loveable rambling old nan who's been at the brandy.
Israeli director Eran Riklis's drama boasts a gentle nuance and emotive humour.

Survive the opening five minutes of his realist/fabulist noir - an unrelentingly slow pan up the side of an industrial ship - without chewing your seat or howling and you'll find plenty to stroke your chin over.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Oscar-nominated director Robert Dornhelm wisely doesn't try anything too tricksy with this studioset adaptation of Puccini's opera.
Unlike the more smart-alek Shrek, this modern fairy tale is more one for families/children despite its sophisticated narrative and enchantingly quirky touches.
Horror fans will find little to sink their teeth into, but it'll get tweenage hearts fluttering like orgasmic bats.
It's a thoroughly enjoyable romp - the cinematic equivalent of a bath-full of Quality Street.
It's little more than an enjoyable enough excuse to put the increasingly droopyjowled Carrey through the expected variety of rubberfaced situations. Should you see it? Yeahbutnobutmaybe.
This unfunny studio comedy is so downright demeaning I ended up hating not only it but my entire gender - and most specifically myself for secretly quite wanting to watch it.

It's as much a magnificent comeback for director Darren Aronofsky (after the grand, over-digitised folly of The Fountain) as it is for Rourke, and there's a beautifully understated authenticity to this funny yet bleak, low-budget triumph.
This is a film that wisely opts for maximum in-your-face splatter and minimal suspense.

This preposterous, patience-draining, ponderous, Pay It Forward-style nonsense, from Gabriele Muccino, the director of The Pursuit Of Happyness, basically amounts to a big pile of backslapping on behalf of the ever-watchable Smith.
Despite the shameless Trekkie jokes and the fact it resembles a Martin Clunes sitcom, there's many a gentle chuckle to be enjoyed in this comedy about 'unleashing the hero within'.
A joy to watch its multi-award-nominated actors spar.
It's a tough but rewarding watch.
Everyone does a jolly good job, including X-Men director Bryan Singer, as the conspiracy plot offers adequate tension and bores sturdily onwards.
Another accomplished, subtle piece by American Beauty director Sam Mendes (aka Mr Kate Winslet), this looks like a super-gorgeous episode of Mad Men.
It's a big surprise to find that The House Of Mouse's first 3D cartoon is such a sophisticated jobbie.

All Oscar ingredients are present and correct - even Tilda Swinton popping up as the token Brit thesp being marvellous in a supporting role - but if this is the best film of 2008 then you can't help feeling it wasn't much of a year.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The drama is tense and claustrophobic, and the acting exceptional, although the hollow finale leaves you doubting it's about anything much at all.
I was gagging for a good, fun, brainless chick-flick fix. And gagging's exactly what I ended up doing throughout most of this latest inexplicable exercise in making me despise my own gender.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A creaky, below-par Brit heist caper that belongs in a dusty vault itself.
The sort of soapy schmaltz you feel dirty for watching. Frankly, if you consider this kind of sugar-coated medical tragedy entertainment, then you're the sick one.
A beautifully observed study of childhood that's unmissable, whatever your age.

Who'd ever have thought you'd be able to complain that a Burton film wasn't disturbing enough? If it wasn't for Johnny Depp's blissfully demented Mad Hatter, this would have all the suggestive menace of a pink fairy cake.
This has the potential to become a camp classic of UK cinema, with the mundane British setting amusingly at odds with the disaster-thriller delivery.
There's almost no plot and just two other minor characters but Prince Avalanche is a haunting, eccentric and ultimately touching little curio.
To say you don't like an upbeat British film this unpretentiously nice is like saying you don't like tea and biscuits.
Mixing Gloria Steinem and gross-out gags with messy aplomb, first-time writer/director Maggie Carey has created a landmark romcom.
The only problem is that, with so much fascinating material to cover, The Crash Reel skips over half of it.
The history is sketchy, the central questions unresolved, the romance is tepid and [Matthew] Fox is a weak, uninteresting lead.
This well-acted dramedy is a ploddingly earnest look at addiction and recovery.
Oscar-nominated former child star [Saoirse] Ronan is a reason enough to see any film.
The leads, including a demeaned Gemma Arterton, are sparkling high-rollers but no one really emerges a winner from this forgettable low-risk, low-stakes drama.

With all the makings of a cult, this hit-and-miss hoot is as weird - and certainly much sillier than you'd expect - of a comedy produced by Stefanie 'Twilight' Meyer but directed/penned by the co-writer of Napoleon Dynamite.

Happiness is shown to be elusive in this astute study of aspiration and delusion that leaves you hanging on a melancholy note. If this should prove to be [Woody] Allen's last film, he will have gone out on a high.
Rigorously researched yet repetitive, it never quite hits the button.
There's the odd giggle and diverting adult support from Samuel L Jackson, Snoop Dogg and Paul Giamatti but the ideal audience age range here is knee high to grasshopper.
Moore deploys every weapon going, from real-life sob stories and sub-GCSE-level economics to an eye-opening anti-banker investigation, with hit-and-miss results.
Tiresomely and implausibly shot entirely as if found footage, this female-written horror is Rosemary's Baby for the Paranormal Activity generation.
As a portrait of one man's all-consuming persistence alone, it's astonishing.
The only film directed by actor Charles Laughton, this haunting masterpiece is simply one of the best horrors ever made.
Add the visionary direction by Steve McQueen, the British Turner Prize-winning artist turned film-maker (Hunger, Shame) and you have an out-and-out stunner.
It's well acted, with a few moments of remarkable intensity, but it's not a journey you'd rush to take.
A sentimental exploration of what fatherhood means that doesn't overdo it with the sperm gags, it's a rather charming if unexceptional dramedy.
Arnaud des Pallières's dreary French costume drama might have been called Robin Hood And His Very Un-Merry Men.
movie_title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas (2014)

movie_review_blurb: More exquisite than ever thanks to a 4K restoration, Jean Cocteau's dreamy 1946 black-and-white retelling of Beauty And The Beast is a real spellbinder.
movie_title: Beauty and The Beast (La Belle et la bête) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: Dench is, of course, magnificent.
The film is full of the nostalgic charm of the cartoon series and wittily references the fact it is entirely made out of fingerprint-smudged bricks in a way Lego Batman kind of forgot.

It's another goofily imaginative movie for teenagers made by middle-aged comic book fans. What's lacking this time is the sparky relationship between Firth's avuncular gent and Egerton's scrappy yoof.
Hollywood bad boy Shia LaBeouf is perfect as former tennis bad boy John McEnroe. He slams in a career-best turn in what's otherwise a largely inert sports movie.

The film has roused censure for glorifying crime, with scant, awkwardly realised minutes paid to Belfort's eventual comeuppance. But surely 71-year-old Scorsese, a one-time wannabe priest whose work is preoccupied with morality, did that deliberately?
This is a rare sequel that enhances, arguably even surpasses, the mastery of its original. Harrison Ford dubbed it 'a cathedral' of a movie and he's right - this is one to worship.
Stay put and you'll find this syrupy love story akin to being mercilessly waterboarded by cupcakes.
The film's real muscle - intelligently never over-flexed - is as an allegory in the balance of global power and the value of life.
Essentially, it's Cars retold with planes. Small, undiscerning kiddies will probably love it and demand the DVD on repeat; adults will be nosediving into their popcorn with boredom.
This is nicely accomplished migrant melodrama from debuting Kurdish-Austrian film-maker Umut Dağ, realised with humanity and tremendously touching performances (particularly from the women).
Tibet is doomed: that's the gloomy take-away from this lengthy, sporadically illuminating examination of the ongoing fallout from China's bloody 1950 occupation.
movie_title: When the Dragon Swallowed the Sun (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Guess what? It's not actually that bad.

Initially a tinglingly edgy and realistic portrait of girl power in an age when female sexuality was considered an unclear but present danger to society, this frustratingly unravels over 143 minutes into something increasingly woolly and unconvincing.
Veering between relationship intrigues and farce, this is not especially moving or particularly funny and yet it's very well acted and quirkily genial.
A multimillion dollar pile of tedium.

Hopping from small to big screen is a trick few manage. This wisely and bravely keeps it small-scale and local - playing out like a slightly over-stretched TV special rather than a doomed attempt to lap-dance to Hollywood with A Good Day To Die Partridge
Determinedly non-preachy, non-bitter and rapturously uplifting.
This is the kind of by-the-book, no-surprises, 'based on actual events' serial killer thriller you could write yourself.
A sombre, low-key, male mid-life crisis drama, full of meaningful glances, unspoken resentment and underlying regret.
It's less a movie than a series of seminar notes.
As implausible macho nonsense goes, it's surprisingly good.
Where Shaun Of The Dead was inspired, this is comfortingly repetitive. But hey, isn't that the main attraction of any pub?
It's older, fatter but as sublimely silly as ever, with ba-da-bing! timing and a finale of celebrity cameo craziness.

When the wisecracking dialogue occasionally shuts up and the jerky pace slows down, you notice the astonishing CGI detailing. Otherwise, this boasts all the flair, heart and originality of an inbred sea cucumber.
Anyone over the age of nine should avoid. Strenuously.
It's a sly film that slips through your fingers, leaving the glitter of great performances, but one you'll be hustling to watch again.
A cinema-lover's delight.
[Rama] Burshtein oppressively captures the claustrophobia of a close-knit community where every daily act - from opening a door to eating - is a religious ritual.
It's like watching a movie in another language.
The CGI animals are spectacular, the battles less so and, though none of it really makes sense, neither, some might argue, does the Bible.
This feels like a really, really, expensive episode of Doctor Who. In a good way.
this mysterious masterpiece seduces you into a very different twilight zone of unforgettable sci-fi strangeness.
Strong, beautiful and honest film-making.

Starship Troopers, Alien, Tron and Star Trek also make up the movie's DNA but the story - a provocative study about the morality of warfare and conflicts of leadership - injects something powerful and new into the familiar 'chosen one' plot trajectory.
What keeps [Mandela: Long Walk] anchored is a towering, Golden Globe-nominated performance from Idris Elba
Movie rule 12: Mistrust anything bearing a '2' in its title - particularly when it's not a sequel. But 2 Guns proves a totally unexpected exception.
Not so much a stinker of a movie as a bafflingly incomplete one, The Dark Tower has presumably been inflicted with so many cuts it's like watching a 95-minute trailer.
Actor-turned-director Stanley Tucci's fifth movie is like an engagingly acted episode stretched into a feature.
Strong, excitingly unpredictable stuff, this is a fabulously unforgettable genre cocktail from Martin (In Bruges) McDonagh.

If you don't already consider 'Clapton is God', as the famous graffiti put it, then you'll be unconverted by this oddly distancing rock doc...Diverting enough, it nonetheless fails to fully delve into its subject.
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Mark Wahlberg is its only under-par member but both Plummers are on the money, while Williams works wonders with her one-note role. Then there's 80-year-old Scott's nimble direction.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [Mike White's] movie tucks some quietly resonant aces up its sleeve - including some fine 'serious acting' from Stiller, arguably his best to date.
Based on real events, this tale of a talented woman trying to make it in a Hollywood stacked against her gains extra currency in the post-Weinstein climate.
Streep, Hanks and Spielberg deliver quality news in this journalistic thriller that's out to be this year's Spotlight.
With fishy-looking types at every turn, it's like a high-speed Murder On The Orient Express with more face punching.
Funny and heart-tugging with some knockout tunes, the movie glows with warmth. And how many kids' cartoons would include a running Frida Kahlo gag? One to treasure.

Shot over five years, their observational, gently woven elegy to the last gasp of celluloid feels somewhat overstretched at feature length, yet it contains some of the most magical images you'll see this year.
Despite swoonsome visuals, it's a constricting, prickly and demanding film, the portrait of a very odd love affair shot through a very male lens...Think Fifty Shades Of Grey for the couture crowd.
[Denzel] Washington is perfectly good but the script doesn't give him enough to make this worthy of all the attention.
Director Saul Dibb (Bullet Boy) brings a tense immediacy to this stagey chamber piece.

Director Joe (Atonement) Wright exhibits his trademark flashes of visual aplomb and captures the peril of Nazi invasion with thrilling immediacy, despite being almost entirely confined to the claustrophobic corridors of power.
[Colin] Firth is all at sea but this retelling of Donald Crowhurst's round-the-world adventure should still keep you hooked
[Andrey] Zvyagintsev layers on his themes of the inhumanity of man and the bleak effects of our self-obsessed culture, yet with the lightness of falling snow.
A fresh new Marvel superhero movie unlike any other.
This is a mesmerising, profoundly emotional tale of vulnerable outsiders - and it's beyond gorgeous to look at.
For anyone who has ever had therapy or contemplated it, it's a rare and illuminating peek into the mechanics of the process.
movie_title: You Have No Idea How Much I Love You (Nawet nie wiesz, jak bardzo cie kocham) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One of the finest teen comedies ever. Movie perfection
[Margot] Robbie's sympathetic yet complicated performance imbues it with truth and pathos.
The power of Barnard's visionary style shines through regardless but this will go down in the annals of film history as one of her lesser works.

It looks great and there are moments of gripping spy-thriller tension as well as those of truly unwatchable torture. But within 15 minutes I was already bored by the plot - a problem when over two hours still stretched ahead.
With not a bone of originality on display, the plot is a sleep-inducing tangle of 'please make it stop now' incoherence, while the poor dubbing doesn't help matters.
Vega's performance is transfixing.
An intense and brutal thriller, this is our millennium's Taxi Driver
[Nicholas] Cage's best in years.
A feminist spin to the characterisation is a plus but this is something parents will stick on for the kids while they get on with something more gripping, like folding laundry.
movie_title: Tad the Lost Explorer and the Secret of King Midas (Tadeo Jones 2: El secreto del Rey Midas) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is essentially a training video, calling viewers to activism with the slogan: 'If our leaders refuse to lead, our citizens will.' If we could only plug our grid into Gore, we'd have an inexhaustible supply of renewable energy.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating testimony to the uplifting power of cinema.
There's a refreshing gender balance among the key characters. Laura Dern's Vice Admiral Holdo may be dressed more for the opera but don't be fooled, kids.
Ultimately, you may be left pondering not so much the allegory as to why [Darren] Aronofsky would want to push not just his audience but his girlfriend through such an extreme wringer.
With a generic title like American Assassin, this sounds like a Chuck Norris straight-to-DVD action flick. It's only a slight upgrade.
A spiky script that skewers the contemporary liberal elite is clearly relished by the splendid cast.

Director David Bruckner makes the most of the misty, twiggy Scandi location to conjure a memorable sense of unease, while his cut-above cast are believable as early middle-aged blokes whose once close friendship is tested.
Occasionally a delightfully intimate filmic device, it soon wears thin and will frustrate Wolf Alice fans since the band mainly waft about in the background.
Witty and scarily pertinent to almost any organisation, The Death Of Stalin is so brilliant it's a privilege to watch it.
A fascinating witch's brew of absurdism, realism, satire and fairy tale, I Am Not A Witch reveals young Zambian-Welsh director/writer Rungano Nyoni as a blazing talent to watch.
[Vince] Vaughn is captivating in his vulnerable, forlorn-eyed, rage-fuelled intensity. More than anything, it's him that compels you to watch through these 132 demolishing minutes.
Weirdness, total weirdness.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Norwegian director Joachim Trier refuses to stick either his characters or the forces guiding them into neat boxes.
It certainly captures the 'live fast, die young' glamour of the bygone Formula One scene. After all, no one lived faster.

But the secret weapon here is Grant: as a vain, once-A-list actor reduced to advertising doggie dinners, he hams it up with just the right amount of self-loathing. At his finest, no one can do comedy quite like him and this is an incomparable performance.
And there's so much charm (a bull-in-a-china-shop scene is an instant classic) that this family treat will put a smile on your face, a tear in your eye and an extra bada-boom in your heart.
A timely and astute exploration of gender power.
Dee Rees's Deep South melodrama is an instant classic.
Robert Pattinson finally drives a stake through his image as the moony hunk from Twilight with this convincing, career-shifting performance - his finest to date.
Annette Bening is terrific as the effervescent Grahame but it's [Jamie] Bell who works real magic on a role that would otherwise be an adoring (frequently shirtless) puppy dog.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Meanwhile, the triple threat of Sarah Silverman, Alan Cumming and Elisabeth Shue all rolled up in one film is a joy almost too great to bear.
Sublimely scored by Philip Glass, this inspiring, unsentimental portrait not only glows but is an empowering must-see every mother should take her daughter too - or vice versa.
Clooney leaves his black characters short-changed (we barely get to know them) despite his heavy-handed highlighting of US racial injustice.
Director/star James Franco allows us to laugh at Wiseau's atrocious acting, incomprehensible direction and oddball vanity but also encourages us to respect his creative spirit.
The chapter shifts between different characters' perspectives give the narrative unexpected universal nuance, making this more than the syrupy medical weepie it might appear.
Morfydd Clark [is] excellent as Dickens's wife.
[Jake] Gyllenhaal may well get an Oscar nomination for this and deserves to - his every expression is captivating.
Brittle, stiff and frustratingly chopped about in a restless bid to break free from its claustrophobic setting, The Dinner is a far from satisfying feast, despite its appetising cast.
Takashi has lost none of his eye-popping style, blood-soaked energy and madcap wit. This is a groaning sashimi board of slice'n'dice carnage that's decidedly not for the faint of stomach.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For the most part what you get here are raw, non-star performances combined with knockout neon visuals.
There's ample drinking, chauvinism and homophobia and more swearing than you'd hear from a hungover Danny Dyer.
The direction is pitch-perfect; the characters unique and eccentric yet fully realised and the script, woven with absurdist comedy, a marvel
You're Next made me jump out of my seat three times. In scary movie terms that's surely job done.
Amazingly, amid all the overlayered effects whoopla-hoopla, Tarzan still manages to find sufficient time and space to be very boring.
Most of the non-leads are underdrawn but laughs keep coming, only just bouncing this up from three stars to four.
Have you come back from your holiday brimming with buy-your-own-vineyard fantasies? Slake that thirst with this French art house crowd-pleaser.
movie_title: Back to Burgundy (Ce qui nous lie) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Be warned, the wittiest thing about this bite-sized-budget Brit horror is its misleading title.
A must for cult connoisseurs who take their comedy strong and dark.
It wants to be Bourne meets 24, but falls way short of its mark.
A heart-wrenchingly tense survival drama based on 'an incredible true story' of a far more 'homely' looking Spanish family, this is a cut above 1990s eco-disaster movies such as Dante's Peak.

Hugh Jackman delivers a muscular, earnest performance that holds together this diverse ensemble cast - which includes predictable but welcome comic relief from Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter - for the full 158min.
Gangster Squad is slight pulp fiction that offers all-out, balls-to-the-wall action riddled with as many clichés as bullets.
At 81 minutes it could do with being still more bite-sized but it's a must-see morsel for foodies. Eat first - it'll make you ravenous.
Competently directed, if incompetently written, it's hard to discern its point - but if that included making you laugh, it indisputably failed.
It's an intelligently provocative, massively entertaining exercise in postmodern revisionism, highlighting how shamefully few movies Hollywood has ever made about slavery.
It's entertainingly silly stuff with an 'oh, no - they wouldn't?' finale of the ooziest toasted cheese.
The Sessions could easily have slipped into schmaltz, but it's an unexpectedly funny delight, thanks in part to sterling work from Helen Hunt and John Hawkes.
It's an intricate, thought- provoking and (be warned) very talkie study of democracy that is almost entirely schmaltz-free.
The massive plus this gothic teen romance has over Twilight is that it's frequently funny - intentionally.
The action is spectacular but it's incoherently directed, so often you can't tell who's smashing what lorry/jeep/helicopter into what, let alone why.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Wreck-It Ralph is a must-see for anyone who grew up playing 1980s arcade games - and their kids will love it too.
Unfortunately, its laudably ambitious decision to tell Chapman's story via 14 different animation styles and distribute it in 3D makes you long for a straight TV biopic.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The cod-psychologising is a little clunky but [Helen] Mirren's Mrs Hitch is inspiringly ballsy - with a dollop of the vulnerability that made you sob in The Queen.
The movie version of Cirque Du Soleil comes alive when the troupe are showing off their stunts - it's just a shame about the bits in between.
The plot existing solely as a breather in between inserting yet more bullets into yet more heads.
Robert Zemeckis' Flight is worth seeing for Denzel Washington's Oscar-nominated performance as well as a marvellously tense plane crash - but the rest is disappointingly soap opera-esque.
Anything beyond 'Jah' and 'peace and love' is lost in a fog of weed but classic moments such as a perma-stoned Snoop trying to scrump a grapefruit off a tree are unintentionally hilarious.
It's either a sublime work of genius or a drearily pretentious nightmare. Possibly both.

Plausibly acted, if implausibly directed by Craig Zobel (Great World Of Sound), the credulity of this provocative scenario would snap had it not actually happened more than 70 times across 30 US states.
However, its everyday intimacy and episodic structure - the scenes are focused around the family's few prison visits and the dad's precious day releases - are really better suited to TV.
Jack The Giant Slayer had something of an identity crisis.
Jiro thankfully finds time to create an achingly romantic subplot with his love (Emily Blunt), who is gently waning away from TB.
John Curran's unshowy, sunbaked film flashes back to darker motivations... but never tries to over-explain its redoubtable heroine or her 'journey'.
It's the lead performances that are the thing here, not the clichéd screenplay. And boy, these boys are acting so hard they almost sweat their fake tattoos off.
Big laughs are guaranteed here - though only at the expense of what's the first Best Worst Film of 2014.

Director Rob Minkoff (The Lion King) strains too hard for his emotional sucker punch, crassly scored to John Lennon's Beautiful Boy no less; but, that aside, you'll be wagging your tail with pleasure.
Bravely, it offers neither a 'feel-good' nor 'feel-bad' payoff. However, the story's momentum fizzles out, its characters often feeling disconnected from each other and us.
[Felicity Jones'] gorgeously vulnerable, yet seductively secretive performance is generously allowed to be the star turn by a twinkly-eyed Fiennes (who also, elegantly, directs).
Predictable 'oldie' jokes about mobility scooters, farts and 'moobs' abound in a film that can't decide if it's a low-denominator, wobbly-kneed comedy or a hotdog-for-brains version of The Wrestler.
The authentic, first-person narration may represent only voices from Germany, Britain and the US but, even so, the scope is over ambitious.
The ending is pat but the characters' tragic stories linger on, squatting in the darker corners of your mind.
Outrageous gay BF? US love interest? Makeover? Training montage? Climactic dance contest? Hi you guys! Sometimes, though, that's just wonderfully comforting, innit?
It's still an inspired, playful, erotic and gently tender look at our technology co-dependence, relationships and modern loneliness that is, undoubtedly, the love story of 2014.
Heady, indulgent, captivating and drowse-inducing, it's like being trapped inside a slow-spinning Velvet Underground record, stuck on endless repeat.
Outrageous, inspired, infuriating, puerile, confounding, cruel, beautiful, funny - Nymphomaniac is a film you can't dismiss with a simple 'good/not good'.
The gags may lurch from hit to miss but the buff stars' equally toned acting skills and some inspired bit-casting make this one to watch - probably with the girls on home release.
The introductory voice-over... generously still gives you time to dash back to the foyer and demand your money back to watch something less stomach-churning - like escalators going up and down.
I'd heard reports that this film could reduce grown men to tears - but I'm guessing they were just yawning with boredom.
The big box-tick here is that it is the women who ultimately command the impressively surging CGI hordes on both sides.
It's an infinitely rewatchable treat let down only by what Mary Berry might call the plot's 'soggy middle' involving will disputes and prison breaks.
Director David Mackenzie (Hallam Foe, Young Adam) impressively controls his gear shifts from quiet slow burn to explosive, only losing his grip on the soap in a final, gorily melodramatic act.
David Thewlis and teen newcomer Lucas Hedges provide sturdy lifeboats amid the eccentric flights of fancy.
A flair-free, CGI-action-packed sequel that solidly delivers regular set-pieces and punch-ups alongside a thoughtful script that tosses Homeland fans a bone.
It lacks the original's fuzzy heart and the story drags in the middle but the quick-fire scene changes mean you're never too far from the next 'waka, waka, waka'.

It celebrates these women's... genuine, selfless love and devotion to the music itself. And to hear that in an era of get-fame-quick shows such as The Voice, where 'tuning' stars' voices is standard practice, gives you a genuine glow.
Woodley's performance is proof, if proof were needed, that only Jennifer Lawrence can do 'blank-faced teen' compellingly.
If you like comfy slacks and mildly amusing sitcoms, you're in for a ball. I found the ending cheery - mainly because I got to leave.
Tom Hardy drives a car down a motorway for 90 minutes while making some hands-free calls. Not exactly a 'wow' pitch - yet this one-man movie is compelling.
This has the feel-good factor of Anvil! meets The Goonies. See it.

Blending languorous visual sensuality with a driving sense of paranoid urgency, this metaphorical mix of skin-crawling body horror and Lynchian mystery boasts a compelling dream logic that offsets its huge potential for being pretentious studenty twaddle.

A profound and bruising study of a country whose long-suffering inhabitants are cowed into incommunication by various forms of repressive dictatorship, it's another muted triumph from director Cristian Mungiu.
This doesn't merely make Snakes On A Plane look like plausible drama; worse, it's a bit of a drag
It's hardly worth the wait.
I even laughed at the fart guns. I never laugh at fart guns.
Scrape off all that spectacle and it's pretty non-original stuff.
If you want to mosh about in Stone Roses nostalgia, check out Shane Meadows doc Made Of Stone instead.
[An] unforgettably moving documentary.
Favouring long, oblique takes, this is 'slow cinema' so slow that, an hour or so in, even one of its protagonists nods off.
Fizzing with giddy energy, this is the freshest, finest Shakespeare movie version of the 21st century.
It's a plum role for any actor and [Michael] Shannon's performance is Oscar-worthy.
It's like a protracted teen drama with a low-budget supernatural showdown tacked on the end.
Truffaut protégé Claude Miller sadly died shortly after filming but his directorial reputation will rest safer on earlier films such as La Petite Voleuse.

Energetic and upbeat, this draws a fringe over why the band keep self-destructing, making it uninsightful, particularly to the uninitiated. But, hey, let's be honest: who else but true fans are going to watch it anyway?
movie_title: The Stone Roses: Made of Stone (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Light but not slight, it is ultimately tender and sensationally acted, with both stars giving career-topping turns.
An Argentinian life-swap thriller with Viggo Mortensen playing twins? Sounds promising - but Everybody Has A Plan doesn't quite go according to plan.
[An] innovative piece of filmmaking so breathtakingly daring and powerful, it replaces your oxygen with awe.
Plenty of talent is on display in front of and behind the camera in this psychological thriller based on the acclaimed TV miniseries.
Arresting, gory and surprising, this flight-of-horror fantasy is wonderfully acted for post-Twilight vamp lovers craving something altogether eerier but emotionally resonant.

Peculiarly set on proving that puerile gags aren't just for youths, this gross-out comedy, presumably aimed at oldies, is just about watchable thanks to [its] cast...though why they signed up remains utterly mystifying.
Lissom-limbed, dreamily topless girls puffing Gitanes and arguing life and art with bed-headed boys - this is exactly what you'd expect and most likely want of a French art-house film.
If you loved The Hangover but loathed its nastier, cruder, non-hilarious sequel - apart from that quite amusing monkey - you'd be right to approach this threequel with caution.
Pin-sharp observant one minute, appealingly messy the next, this marks [Lake] Bell as one of America's most promising new talents.
This thrilling drama is no more for petrol-heads only than Titanic is solely of interest to historic ship enthusiasts.
Sorrentino's heady, vivid yet wearily melancholic musing on midlife crisis submerges you in sumptuousness until you emerge, blinking, as if from some impossibly glamorous party.

It's pretty clear that Imhoof is not a fan of US industrial-scale farming but rather than shove angry stats such as '80 per cent of plants rely on bee pollination' in your face, he prefers to fascinate viewers.
The film's heart is in the right place but it never rises above the level of a polemical melodrama.
For [Michael Bay], storytelling exists only to justify senselessly bashing some big shiny noisy stuff into other big noisy shiny stuff till your ears bleed for mercy.
It smells less like teen spirit than money, yet it bottles the carefree zest of pure pop so irresistably even non-Directioners will find themselves happily bip-bip-bopping along.

What could be, and largely is, a load of old lefties banging on about the wonders of golden age socialism, is also very much intended as a rallying call to action before the last vestiges of state ownership are tossed to the capitalists.
An entertaining and deeply unsettling premonition of the state the US's obsession with guns may leave it in.
There are some terrific one-liners, most of them insults...But this is a string of character gags, not a film, and the narrative barely putters along.
Preachy, draggingly directed by M Night Shyamalan and just not much fun.

Hallucinogenic black-and-white visuals, eerie sounds, sporadic splatter and potentially insufferable philosophising are blessedly leavened with earthy humour. Think Tarkovsky's Stalker meets Monty Python's Holy Grail.
One for hard-core gore-hounds.
Fetid, scuzzy, revolting, funny, erotic, perplexing and provocative, it's like the bastard child of Cape Fear, Written On The Wind and Killer Joe.
With its silly, glittery costumes and warring stars, this basically does for magic what Blades Of Glory did for ice skating.

With flying monkeys, Yellow Brick Road and sequin-spangled witches all faithfully reproduced, it's impossible to see this as a standalone film, given it looks like an HD colouring book version of the original movie.

Ageing, isolation, broken families, memory and the impact of modern technology are all playfully woven through a smart, comforting narrative that's at once immensely satisfying yet wonderfully unexpected.
In other hands this would be an anti-fame morality tale. In Coppola's it's more of an elegant glide-by, her finest 'lost rich girl' comedy-drama since Lost In Translation.
A bit 'eww' in that it's essentially a romcom with a mom and son, it's the perfect Mother's Day outing for people who don't like their mums much.
Director Rufus Norris bleakly contrasts ugly acts of violence with innocent pockets of childhood in this simple yet richly nuanced film.
Treat yourself: buy the pick'n'mix but skip the film.
How long can writer Nicholas Sparks trade off his iconic blub-fest The Notebook?
Funny and heart-warming, it's a bit like Amour meets The Voice and The Full Monty.
Once seen, this is seared in your heart, deep as your worst relationship break-up.
movie_title: Grave of the Fireflies (Hotaru no haka) (1988)

movie_review_blurb: It's compiled with obvious affection and director Tony Britten (no relation) scores coups whenever he sets his camera in front of a choir, soloist or string quartet and lets the music sing and soar for itself.
A cracking story, buzzily edited, this warts-and-warts portrait delivers an illuminating insight into recent rock history. Don't miss it.

Poor J-Lo: there was a time when she co-starred with George Clooney, but 15 years on from Out Of Sight she's just a third wheel in this uninspired vengeance caper wherein The Stath is shafted by the Mob and vows payback.
This is authentic, nail-digging life and death drama that, like Borgen, is all about maturing character development and power politics.
It's a cracking true story and the cast, including an impossibly free-spirited and leggy Tamsin Egerton, are outstanding but beneath the smart one-liners, frustratingly little is laid bare.

Pulling off the trick of being both irreverent and Trekkie-pleasing, JJ Abrams effortlessly orchestrates massive action set pieces, a galaxy of 'cor look at that' CGI effects and well-modulated character scenes.
Here's a good rule of thumb: never trust anything bearing an exclamation mark.
Like flicking through the pages of Vogue whilst sipping a martini.
